* *PHYS** **[N]****1001** **[/N]** **Essential Physics****[T1][/T1]**

# Course Description

| This course covers the essential concepts of physics in mechanics, heat, electricity and magnetism, waves, atoms, and nuclei. It aims to bring out the essential concepts and their relevance, using simple mathematics. Secondary school physics and calculus are not required. It is suitable for students in physical sciences, biological and medical sciences, and earth science who lack the basic physics training in secondary school, and for students in other majors who want to learn the essential concepts of physics for their later courses. Pre-requisite: 1. For JUPAS entrants without attending HKDSE Physics or Combined Science with Physics component, including absentees. 2. For non-JUPAS students, please seek advice and permission from the Department of Physics. Grade Descriptor A : Demonstrate thorough mastery of principles and subject matter in the course required for attaining all the course learning outcomes. Demonstrate the ability to apply the principles or subject matter to familiar and unfamiliar situations, in a manner that would surpass the normal expectation at this level and standards that may be required at higher levels of study or research. Has the ability to express the knowledge or synthesis of ideas in a clear and cogent manner. A- : Demonstrate substantial command of principles and subject matter in the course required for attaining almost all the course learning outcomes. Demonstrate the ability to state and apply the principles or subject matter to familiar and some unfamiliar situations, in a manner that is logical and comprehensive. Has the ability to express the knowledge or application with clarity and accuracy. B : Demonstrate general and sufficient command of principles and subject matter in the course required for attaining most of the course learning outcomes. Demonstrate the ability to state and apply the principles or subject matter accurately to most (but not necessarily all) familiar and standard situations, in a manner that is logical and persuasive. Has the ability to express the knowledge or application in a satisfactory and unambiguous way. C : Demonstrate general command of principles and subject matter in the course required for attaining some of the course learning outcomes. Demonstrate the ability to state and apply the principles or subject matter to most (but not necessarily all) familiar and standard situations, but with occasional errors and/or in a manner that is fragmented. Has the ability to express the separate pieces of knowledge in an unambiguous way. D : Demonstrate partial command of principles and subject matter in the course required for attaining some of the course learning outcomes. Demonstrate the ability to state and apply the principles or subject matter to some simple situations only. Has the ability to state the knowledge or application in simple terms. F : Demonstrate little or no evidence of command of principles and subject matter in the course required for attaining the course learning outcomes, OR failure to meet specified assessment requirements. |
| --- |

# Course Content

| | Topics | **Highlights of Fundamental Concepts** |
| --- | --- | --- |
| 1. | Mechanics Particle kinematics and dynamics | A.Describing motion: mass, force, equilibrium, speed and velocity, accelerationB.Newton’s laws of motion: Newton’s law, forces, vectorsC.Momentum and Energy: Momentum, impulse, conservation of momentum, collisions, energy, work, potential energy, kinetic energy, work-energy theorem, conservation of energy, powerD.Gravity: Universal law of gravitation, inverse-square law, weight, projectile motion, satellites |
| 2. | Heat | Temperature, heat, internal energy, Laws of thermodynamics, entropy, specific heat capacity, expansion, heat transfer, cooling, global warming and greenhouse effect, change of phase |
| 3. | Electricity | Electric force and charge, Coulomb’s law, electric field, electric potential, voltage sources, electric current, resistance, Ohm’s law, electric circuits, electric power |
| 4. | Magnetism | Magnetic fields, electric currents and magnetic fields, forces on moving charges, electromagnetic induction, generators, transformer |
| 5. | Waves and Sound | Vibration and waves, wave motion, transverse and longitudinal waves, sound waves, resonance, interference, beats, standing waves, Doppler’s effect, shock waves, musical sounds |
| 6. | Light | Electromagnetic spectrum, transparent and opaque materials, color, why the sky is blue, sunsets are red, and clouds are white, diffraction, interference, reflection, refraction, dispersion, total internal reflection, lenses, polarization |
| 7. | The Atom | Electron, proton, neutrons, photoelectric effect, emission spectrum, lasers, double-slit experiments, wave-particle duality, particle as waves: electron diffraction, electron waves, probability clouds and atomic orbitals |
| 8. | The Nucleus | Radioactivity, alpha, beta, gamma rays, environmental radiation, nuclei and nuclear force, half-life, transmutation of elements, radiometric dating, fission and fusion |

* *Coverage: Ch.3-6, 7-16 of Paul G. Hewitt, “Concept Physics Fundamentals” or equivalent**

# Learning Outcomes

By the end of the course, students will be able to:

| 1. | state and describe physical principles in major branches of physics including mechanics, heat, electricity and magnetism, light, atom, and nucleus |
| --- | --- |
| 2. | apply simple quantitative methods to solve physics problems |
| 3. | using physics principles to explain physical phenomena in unfamiliar situations |
| 4. | recognize the relationship between physics and other branches of science |

# Course Content

| | Topics | **Highlights of Fundamental Concepts [*Discussion will be focused on the boldfaced topics*]** |
| --- | --- | --- |
| 1. | Particle kinematics and dynamicsParticle kinematics and dynamics | **Vectors**; motion in one, two and three dimensions; **projectile motion**, Newton's laws, force and motion; **circular motion**; work, kinetic energy, **potential energy**, **conservation of energy** |
| 2. | Rotational Motion | **Rotational kinematics, rotational inertia, Kepler’s laws, torque, condition of equilibrium, Newton's second law for rotation, work and rotational kinetic energy, rolling, angular momentum, conservation of angular momentum** |
| 3. | Fluids | **Pressure, Pascal's principle, Archimedes' principle, fluid flow and equation of continuity, Bernoulli's equation** |
| 4. | Temperature, Ideal Gas, Energy in Thermal Processes | Temperature and zeroth law of thermodynamics, temperature scales, expansion of solids and liquids, macroscopic description of an ideal gas, **kinetic theory of gases** Heat and internal energy, specific heat, phase change and latent heat, energy transfer, **specific heat of ideal gas, selected applications** |
| 5. | Laws of Thermodynamics | **Thermodynamic processes, First law, reversible and irreversible processes, Second Law, Carnot cycle, entropy, statistical interpretation of entropy, Third Law** |
| 6. | Oscillations | **Simple harmonic motion and uniform circular motion, period and frequency of SHM, pendulum, damped oscillations, forced oscillators and resonance** |
| 7. | Electric Potential | A quick review on electric force and fields, **electric potential energy, electric potential, relation between electric field and potential, capacitors, dielectrics, energy stored in a capacitor** |
| 8. | Current and Circuits | Electric current, emf, resistance, Ohm’s law, **Kirchhoff’s rule**, series and parallel circuits, power and energy in circuits, **RC circuits**, electrical safety, selected applications |
| 9. | Electromagnetic Waves | Hertz’s confirmation of Maxwell’s prediction on EM waves, EM spectrum, **properties of EM waves**, **energy transport by EM waves**, **polarization** |
| 10. | Early Quantum Theory | **Blackbody radiation, photoelectric effect, X-ray production, X-ray diffraction, Compton effect, spectroscopy and early models of the atom, Bohr’s model of H-atom, atomic energy levels** |
| 11. | Nuclear Physics | Nuclear structure, binding energy, radioactivity, decay rates and half-lives, biological effects of radiation, induced nuclear reactions, fission, fusion, medial applications of radiation |

* *Coverage: Ch.2-6, 8-10, 13-15, 17, 18, 22, 27, 29 of “Physics” by Giambattista, Richardson and Richardson (McGrawHill 2008) (or later edition), or equivalently**

* *Ch. 2-5, 7-13, 16-18, 22, 27, 29, 30 of “Serway’s College Physics” by Faughin, Serway, Vuille, and Bennett (7th edition, Thomson 2006) (or later edition).**

By the end of the course, students will be able to:

| 1. | Gain an understanding on topics in mechanics, thermodynamics, electricity, and modern physics that supplement those in HKDSE Physics |
| --- | --- |
| 2. | Obtain the important background for students to pursue a major in science and other disciplines |
| 3. | Appreciate the relevance of physics, especially its fundamental role in difference fields in science and engineering |
| 4. | Acquire some problem solving skills |
| 5. | Appreciate the quantitative nature of physics |

# Course Content

| | Topics | **Highlights of Fundamental Concepts** |
| --- | --- | --- |
| 1. | Newton’s Laws of Motion and Applications Particle kinematics and dynamicsVecorV | Force and Mass; Newton's First Law of Motion, Newton's Second Law of Motion; Newton's Third Law of Motion; The Vector Nature of Forces (in Two Dimension); Weight; Normal Forces; Frictional Forces; Strings and Springs; Translational Equilibrium; Connected Objects; Circular Motion. |
| 2. | Fluids | Density; Pressure; Static Equilibrium in Fluids: Pressure and Depth; Archimedes’ Principle and Buoyancy; Applications of Archimedes’ Principle; Fluid Flow and Continuity; Bernoulli’s Equation; Applications of Bernoulli’s Equation; Viscosity and Surface Tension. |
| 3. | Temperature and Heat | Temperature and the Zeroth Law of Thermodynamics; Temperature Scales; Thermal Expansion; Heat and Mechanical Work; Specific Heats; Conduction, Convection, and Radiation. |
| 4. | Laws of Thermodynamics | The Zeroth Law of Thermodynamics; The First Law of Thermodynamics; Thermal Processes; Specific Heats for an Ideal Gas: Constant Pressure, Constant Volume; The Second Law of Thermodynamics; Heat Engines and the Carnot Cycle; Refrigerators, Air Conditioners, and Heat Pumps; Entropy; Order, Disorder, and Entropy; The Third Law of Thermodynamics. |
| 5. | Electric Field and Potential | Electric Charge; Insulators and Conductors; Coulomb’s Law; The Electric Field; Electric Field Lines; Shielding and Charging by Induction; Electric Flux and Gauss’s Law; Electric Potential Energy and the Electric Potential; Energy Conservation; The Electric Potential of Point Charges; Equipotential Surfaces and the Electric Field; Capacitors and Dielectrics; Electrical Energy Storage. |
| 6. | Current and DC Circuit | Electric Current; Resistance and Ohm’s Law; Energy and Power in Electric Circuits; Resistors in Series and Parallel; Kirchhoff’s Rules; Circuits Containing Capacitors; RC Circuits; Ammeters and Voltmeters. |
| 7. | EM waves | The Production of Electromagnetic Waves; The Propagation of Electromagnetic Waves; The Electromagnetic Spectrum; Energy and Momentum in Electromagnetic Waves; Polarization. |

# Learning Outcomes

By the end of the course, students will be able to:

| 1. | state and describe the principles in Newton's Laws of motion,Fluids, Heat and Laws of Thermodynamics, Electricity, Circuits, EM waves, within a formalism using vectors and elementary mathematics (non-calculus) |
| --- | --- |
| 2. | apply these principles and some mathematical methods (non-calculus) to physics or/and engineering problems |
| 3. | employessential physics skills for solving engineering problems |

courses.description:
(UGEB1506 is double-coded with PHYS1004.)
The course aims at revealing the fundamental role that physics principles have been playing in the development of science and technology (S&T), which has drastically changed our ways of living and understanding of nature. Successful stories on the evolution of S&T in human history are introduced in the perspectives of STEM, i.e., from the discovery of fundamental Scientific (Physics) (S) principles, to applying the principles to Technological (T) innovations, solving Engineering (E) problems to make the applications viable, and with Mathematics (M) as the essential language that encompasses the whole process. Modern technology is also shown to change the ways of modern scientific investigation and accelerate human understanding of the physical world in an unprecedented speed. Science related social issues are used to help students understand the importance of using science principles and knowledge in making judgements and informed decisions. Lively demonstrations, lab visit, and STEM activities are used in class to (1) illustrate basic physics principles, (2) make physics principles more connected to students’ daily life applications, and (3) better prepare students for explaining science concepts and conducting basic educational STEM activities as an educator, publisher, reporter, and in other S&T related disciplines in the future. Secondary school physics are not required to take this course.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing the course, students should be able to:

* Explain and apply some fundamental physics principles in non-technical terms.
* Create, plan, and conduct basic STEM education activities related to physics and explain the underlying principles.
* Explain and exemplify the interplay between science and technology, especially on how fundamental physics principles have evolved into innovative applications that changed the world, and how the advance in technology has accelerated our understanding of nature.
* Recognize and appreciate the generality and beauty of physics principles and be aware of its working in nature, its impacts on technology and daily life.
* Recognize and appreciate mathematics as the language of physical sciences and its fundamental role in all forms of engineering.
* Analyze scientific information in public media and popular science contexts; and think critically on science related issues.
* Make judgements and informed decisions based on science principles and knowledge.
* Be motivated to learn about science and technology as a part of life-longed learning.
courses.course_syllabus:
Major topics (nos. in […] refer to the references in Section 8):

* Motions and Energy: Motion and inertia; Newton’s second law of motion, friction, momentum, applications of these concepts on traffic and road safety; energy and power, and examples including chemical changes in digesting food and explosion; different sources of energy and their environmental impacts [1,2,4,5].
* Amazing Fluids: Basic introduction to the concepts of fluids such as density, pressure, viscosity, fluid resistance, diffusion and turbulence; basic principles of flying machines from frisbee to airplane; interactions of fluids with micro-particles, face masks and COVID-19 prevention [1,2,15].
* Wonders of Light: Basic geometrical and wave properties of light, reflection, refraction, dispersion, diffraction and interference, and daily life applications; light-atom interactions, emission and absorption spectra, spectrometry and applications; basic principles of laser and its modern applications: optical fibre, laser surgery, optical tweezers, fluorescence imaging; blue LED and applications [1,2,3,9,10,11,12].
* Beyond Light: Maxwell’s discovery of electromagnetic waves, electromagnetic spectrum, ionizing and non-ionizing radiations; uses of non-ionizing radiations including communication, temperature measurements, and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI); applications, hazards, and safety of ionizing radiations.
* Ultracold world: Temperature, heat and basic heat transfer mechanisms; change of phases, phase diagram and factors affecting phase changes, change in material properties on cooling, basic concepts on superconductivity and its applications such as magnetic levitation and MRI [1,2,3,5,6,8,9,13,14].
* Going Small: Structure of atoms and dual nature of elementary particles, basic quantum phenomena, electrons and electron microscopes, constructing and seeing nanostructures, present and future applications [1,3,4,6,8,9].

Essential skills and concepts taught together with the topics above [4,5,7]:

* Educational demonstration experiments and STEM activities for conveying basic physics concepts and the underlying principles of technological applications.
* Interpreting and presenting science information in a non-technical way, understanding the degree of confidence of scientific experiments, popularizing science, awareness of the risk of distortion and exaggeration, ethics in conveying science information.
* The roles of mathematics in physics and technology are illustrated with exemplars on (1) the importance of precision and accuracy in scientific measurements, (2) how the order of magnitude of physical quantities crucially affect the outcomes of physical phenomena, and (3) how mathematical derivations deliver essential results that go much beyond qualitative understanding.

# Course Description

| This introductory calculus-based course discusses the basic principles of mechanics, fluids and waves. The course assumes a good background of HKDSE Physics, Mathematics and Mathematics Extended Part Module 2. It is suitable for students admitted to the ESTP stream in Physics; it is also open to potential majors in physics, mathematics and other physical sciences who have the necessary background and upon the approval of the instructor. Topics include: particle kinematics, force and motion, work and kinetic energy, potential energy, momentum, systems of particles and collisions, rotation, Newton’s law of gravitation, fluid statics and the dynamics of ideal fluids, oscillations, and waves. Students are advised to take this course concurrently with an introductory mathematics course that includes vectors and calculus. Not for students taken PHYS1111. |

# Course Content

| | Topics | **Highlights of Fundamental Concepts** |
| --- | --- | --- |
| 1. | Particle kinematics and dynamicsParticle kinematics and dynamics | Vectors and scalars; motion in one, two and three dimensions; Newton's laws, force and motion; circular motion; work, kinetic energy, potential energy, conservation of energy. [Elementary calculus will be assumed, and only reviewed very quickly.] |
| 2. | Systems of particles | Center of mass, linear momentum, impulse, Newton's second law for a system of particles, collisions. |
| 3. | Rotation | Rotational kinematics, rotational inertia, torque, Newton's second law for rotation, work and rotational kinetic energy, rolling, angular momentum, conservation of angular momentum. |
| 4. | Gravitation | Newton's law of gravitation, gravitational potential energy, Kepler’s laws. |
| 5. | Fluids | Pressure, Pascal's principle, Archimedes' principle, ideal fluids in flow and equation of continuity, Bernoulli's equation. |
| 6. | Oscillations | Simple harmonic motion, energy in a simple harmonic motion, damped oscillation, forced oscillations and resonance. |
| 7. | Waves | Transverse and longitudinal waves, wavelength and frequency, energy of a travelling string wave, superposition, interference of waves, standing waves, sound waves, the speed of sound, intensity and sound level, interference, beats, Doppler’s effect. |

# Course Description

| This introductory calculus-based course discusses the basic principles of optics, special relativity, and quantum physics and its applications, plus an introduction to particle physics. The course assumes a background of HKDSE Physics. It is suitable for potential majors in science and engineering, and for those who intend to minor in physics. * *Course Status: Elective**

# Course Content

| | Topics | **Highlights of Fundamental Concepts** |
| --- | --- | --- |
| 1. | The Nature and Propagation of Light | The nature of light, with a qualitative discussion on electromagnetic waves, reflection and refraction, total internal reflection, polarization, dispersion, Huygens’ principle |
| 2. | Geometric Optics | Reflection and reflection at a plane surface and a spherical surface, thin lenses, some optical instruments |
| 3. | Interference | Interference and coherent sources, Young’s interference experiment, intensity in interference patterns, interference in thin films, Michelson’s interferometer |
| 4. | Diffraction | Diffraction and wave theory of light, Fresnel and Fraunhofer diffraction, diffraction from a single slit, intensity in single-slit diffraction, multiple slits, diffraction gratings, circular aperture, resolving power |
| 5. | Relativity | Galilean relativity, Einstein’s postulates, relativity of simultaneity, relativity of time intervals, relativity of length, the Lorentz transformation, Lorentz velocity transformation equations, relativistic mementum, relativistic work and energy, mass and energy |
| 6. | Photons, Electrons, and Atoms | Emission and absorption of light, photoelectric effect, atomic line spectra and energy levels, the nuclear atom, Bohr model, X-ray production, the Compton effect, photons and EM waves |
| 7. | The Wave Nature of Particles | de Broglie waves, electron diffraction, double-slit experiment revisited, probability and uncertainty, the electron microscope, wave functions and the Schrodinger equation |
| 8. | Quantum Mechanics | Particle in a box, potential wells, potential barriers and tunneling, harmonic oscillator, (brief) three-dimensional problems |
| 9. | Atomic Physics | The wave function for hydrogen, physical interpretation of the quantum numbers, the Zeeman effect, the electron spin, many-electron atoms and the Pauli exclusion principle, the periodic table, X-ray spectra |
| 10. | Molecules and Solids | Molecular bonds, Molecular spectra, bonding in solids, free-electron model of metals, band theory of solids, electrical conduction in metals, insulators, and semiconductors, semiconductor devices, STM |
| 11. | Nuclear Physics | Some properties of nuclei, nuclear binding and nuclear structure (nuclear force and nuclear models), nuclear stability and radioactivity, decay processes, nuclear reactions, nuclear fission, nuclear fusion, biological effects of radiation, (optional) NMR and MRI |
| 12. | Particle Physics and Cosmology | Some particles, positron and antiparticles, particles as force mediator and the meson, particle accelerators and detectors, particles and interactions, finding patterns in particles, quarks, the standard model and beyond, the Cosmic connection (the expanding universe, the big bang, the standard model and the history of the universe) |

# Learning Outcomes

By the end of the course, students will be able to:

| 1. | describe the basic concepts of optics, special relativity, and quantum physics |
| --- | --- |
| 2. | analyze and solve basic problems in optics and special relativity |
| 3. | apply the concepts of quantum physics to analyze basic one-dimensional bound state problems |
| 4. | state and appreciate applications of quantum mechanics in microscopic situations |
| 5. | have the necessary background for relevant upper-level courses. |

* *PHYS 1712 - Physics Laboratory I****[/T]**

* *T1]**

# Course Description

| This is a first course in experimental physics, with an aim to help students develop basic skills in performing experimental measurements, handling and utilizing basic equipment, as well as build necessary concepts and attitudes in data and error analysis. The experiments also serve to illustrate the principles and to reinforce the concepts taught in the lecture course PHYS1111. Grade Descriptors A : Demonstrate thorough mastery of principles and experimental techniques in the course required for attaining all the course learning outcomes. Demonstrate the ability to apply the principles and experimental techniques to familiar and unfamiliar situations, in a manner that would surpass the normal expectation at this level and standards that may be required at higher levels of study or research. Has the ability to express the objective, method and data analysis of the experimental study in the form of a report in a clear, cogent and possibly creative manner. A- : Demonstrate substantial command of principles and experimental techniques in the course required for attaining almost all the course learning outcomes. Demonstrate the ability to state and apply the principles and experimental techniques to familiar and some unfamiliar situations, in a manner that is logical and comprehensive. Has the ability to express the objective, method and data analysis of the experimental study in the form of a report with clarity and accuracy. B : Demonstrate general and sufficient command of the principles and experimental techniques in the course required for attaining most of the course learning outcomes. Demonstrate the ability to state and apply the principles and experimental techniques accurately to most (but not all) familiar and standard situations, in a manner that is logical and persuasive. Has the ability to express the objective, method and data analysis of the experimental study in the form of a report in a satisfactory and unambiguous way. C : Demonstrate general command of the principles and experimental techniques in the course required for attaining some of the course learning outcomes. Demonstrate the ability to state and apply the principles and experimental techniques to most (but not necessarily all) familiar and standard situations, in a manner that is not incorrect but is fragmented. Has the ability to express the objective, method and data analysis of the experimental study in the form of a report in a fragmented but unambiguous way. D : Demonstrate partial command of principles and experimental techniques in the course required for attaining some of the course learning outcomes. Demonstrate the ability to state and apply the principles and experimental techniques to some simple situations only. Has the ability to state the objective, method and data analysis of the experimental study in the form of a report in a simple, fragmented way. F : Demonstrate little or no evidence of command of the principles and experimental techniques in the course required for attaining the course learning outcomes, OR failure to meet specified assessment requirements. |
| --- |

* *Course Status: Core**

# Course Content

| | Topics | **Highlights of Fundamental Concepts** |
| --- | --- | --- |
| 1 | Introductory lecture on the basic principles of data and error analysis in experimental physics for beginning students | Measurements and calibrations; accuracy and precision; meaning of errors; data analysis and error analysis; propagation of errors; basic statistical distributions; linear least square fit; use of Excel for data presentation, error estimation and graph plotting; and format of a scientific report. |
| 2 | Laboratory session on ‘Distance measurement with ultrasonic waves’ | The physics of ultrasonic waves and their emission, reflection and detection. Use of equipments including ultrasonic emitter and receiver, amplifier and conventional oscilloscope. |
| 3 | Laboratory session on ‘Doppler Effect’ | Doppler Effect of ultrasonic wave, conservation of energy. Use of equipments including ultrasonic emitter and receiver, amplifier and digital oscilloscope. |
| 4 | Laboratory session on ‘Torsional pendulum’ | The physics of a torsional pendulum, moment of inertia, dimensional analysis. Measurements using a torsional pendulum with wire & strips. |
| 5 | Laboratory session on ‘Frictional force on rolling objects’ | The physics of the friction on rolling objects. Measurement of time. |
| 6 | Laboratory session on ‘Cavendish's Experiment’ | Newton’s universal law of gravitation. The design of Cavendish's famous setup. |
| 7 | Laboratory session on ‘Damped oscillator, forced oscillator and resonance’ | The physics of damped and forced harmonic oscillators, resonance, solutions of second order differential equation. Use of equipments including LRC circuits, digital oscilloscope, digital multimeter and LRZ meter. |
| 8 | Laboratory session on ‘Vibrating string and superposition of waves’ | Superposition of waves in a vibrating string, Fourier analysis, forced oscillation, standing wave and resonance. Use of microphone and digital oscilloscope. |

# Learning Outcomes

By the end of the course, students will be able to:

| 1 | Develop general considerations for the design of a scientific experiment |
| --- | --- |
| 2 | Gain experience of using standard equipment to perform a measurement |
| 3 | Acquire the ability of collecting, analyzing, handling and plotting of data, and estimation of errors by using Excel |
| 4 | Know how to write a concise scientific report |
| 5 | Acquire skills in problem solving, team work, computer usage, and planning a measurement |
| 6 | Recognize the connection between theories and real-life measurements, and appreciate the principles taught in the lecture courses in introductory University Physics. |

* *PHYS** **2041****University Physics III**

* *Introduction to Heat and Electromagnetism**

* *Course Description**

| This is an introductory calculus-based course which discusses the basic principles of thermodynamics and electromagnetism. The course assumesstudents to have a good background of HKDSE Physics (or equivalent) and calculus. This courseis a core course for physics majors. Topics include: the laws of thermodynamics and the kinetic theory of gases; Coulomb’s law, electric field and potential, Gauss’ law, capacitance and dielectrics, current and resistance, DC circuits, magnetic fields, Ampere’s law, Faraday’s law, inductance, AC circuits, Maxwell’s equations and electromagnetic waves. Grade Descriptor A : Demonstrate thorough mastery of principles and subject matter in the course required for attaining all the course learning outcomes. Demonstrate the ability to apply the principles or subject matter to familiar and unfamiliar situations, in a manner that would surpass the normal expectation at this level and standards that may be required at higher levels of study or research. Has the ability to express the knowledge or synthesis of ideas in a clear and cogent manner. A- : Demonstrate substantial command of principles and subject matter in the course required for attaining almost all the course learning outcomes. Demonstrate the ability to state and apply the principles or subject matter to familiar and some unfamiliar situations, in a manner that is logical and comprehensive. Has the ability to express the knowledge or application with clarity and accuracy. B : Demonstrate general and sufficient command of principles and subject matter in the course required for attaining most of the course learning outcomes. Demonstrate the ability to state and apply the principles or subject matter accurately to most (but not necessarily all) familiar and standard situations, in a manner that is logical and persuasive. Has the ability to express the knowledge or application in a satisfactory and unambiguous way. C : Demonstrate general command of principles and subject matter in the course required for attaining some of the course learning outcomes. Demonstrate the ability to state and apply the principles or subject matter to most (but not necessarily all) familiar and standard situations, but with occasional errors and/or in a manner that is fragmented. Has the ability to express the separate pieces of knowledge in an unambiguous way. D : Demonstrate partial command of principles and subject matter in the course required for attaining some of the course learning outcomes. Demonstrate the ability to state and apply the principles or subject matter to some simple situations only. Has the ability to state the knowledge or application in simple terms. F : Demonstrate little or no evidence of command of principles and subject matter in the course required for attaining the course learning outcomes, OR failure to meet specified assessment requirements. |
| --- |

# 

# Course Status: Core (3 units)

* *Course Content** **(Coverage: Chapter 18-33 of HRW)**

| | **Topics** | **Contents** | **Ref. (HRW)** |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| 1. | Temperature, Heat, and the First Law of Thermodynamics | Temperature and the Zeroth law of thermodynamics, thermometers and temperature scales, thermal expansion of solids and liquids, temperature and heat, specific heat and latent heat, heat and work in thermodynamic processes, internal energy and the First law of thermodynamics with applications, energy transfer mechanisms | Ch. 18 |
| 2. | Kinetic Theory of Gases | Molecular model of an ideal gas, pressure and molecular motion, the meaning of temperature, translational kinetic energy, equipartition of energy, mean free path, distribution of molecular speeds, specific heat of an ideal gas, adiabatic processes for an ideal gas | Ch. 19 |
| 3. | Entropy and the Second Law of Thermodynamics | Reversible and irreversible processes, irreversible processes and entropy, the Second Law of thermodynamics, engines and refrigerators, the Carnot cycle, efficiency of real engines, microscopic interpretation of entropy | Ch. 20 |
| 4. | Electric Charge and Electric Field | Electric charge, conductors and insulators, Coulomb’s law, electric field, electric field calculations (point charge, electric dipole, line of charge, continuous charge distribution), electric field lines, charged particle in an electric field, a dipole in an electric field | Ch. 21-22 |
| 5. | Gauss’ Law | Charge and electric flux, Gauss’ Law, applications of Gauss’ Law (cylindrical, planar, spherical symmetries), charged isolated conductor. | Ch. 23 |
| 6. | Electric Potential | Electric potential energy, electric potential and potential difference, equipotential surfaces, calculating the potential from the field, examples (point charges, electric dipole, continuous charge distribution), calculating the field from the potential, potential of a charged isolated conductor, the Millikan oil-drop experiment | Ch. 24 |
| 7. | Capacitance | Capacitors and dielectrics, capacitance, calculating the capacitance, capacitors in series and parallel, energy stored in an electric field, dielectrics (molecular model of induced charge), Gauss’ law in dielectrics | Ch. 25 |
| 8. | Current and Resistance | Electric current, current density, resistance and resistivity, Ohm’s law, free-electron model of resistivity, materials and conductivity, power in electric circuits | Ch. 26 |
| 9. | Direct Current Circuits | Electromotive force, resistors in parallel and in series, Kirchhoff’s rules, electrical measuring instruments (the meters), RC circuit | Ch. 27 |
| 10. | Magnetic Fields | Magnetic fields and forces, motion of a charged particle in a uniform magnetic field, applications (mass spectrometer, cyclotron, and velocity selector), magnetic force on a current carrying wire, torque on a current loop, magnetic dipole moment, the discovery of electron, the Hall effect | Ch. 28 |
| 11. | Sources of the Magnetic Field | Magnetic field due to a current (Biot-Savart Law), magnetic force between two parallel currents, Ampere’s law and its applications, solenoids, a current-carrying coil as a magnetic dipole | Ch. 29 |
| 12. | Induction and Inductance | Induction experiments, Faraday’s law and Lenz’ law, induction and energy transfer (motional emf), induced electric fields, inductors and inductance, self-induction, RL circuits, energy stored in a magnetic field, energy density of a magnetic field, mutual induction. | Ch. 30 |
| 13. | Circuit Oscillators and Alternating Current | Oscillations in LC circuits, damped oscillations in RLC circuits, electrical-mechanical analogy, AC sources, resistors, inductors, and capacitors in AC circuits, series RLC circuits, power in AC circuits, resonance, transformer | Ch. 31 |
| 14. | Maxwell’s Equations and Electromagnetic Waves | The displacement current and the general form of Ampere’s law, Maxwell’s equations (integral form), electromagnetic waves, energy transport and the Poynting vector, radiation pressure, polarization, the electromagnetic spectrum | Ch.32-33 |
| 15. | Magnetism of Matter | Magnets, magnetism and electrons, magnetic materials, diamagnetism, paramagnetism, ferromagnetism | Ch. 32 |

* *Learning Outcomes**

| 1. | Gain an understanding of the fundamental principles of thermodynamics and electromagnetism, within a formalism using vectors and elementary calculus; |
| --- | --- |
| 2. | Acquire the ability to use some mathematical methods, such as vector algebra and calculus, and an appreciation of their roles and applications in thermodynamics and electromagnetism, and the be able to apply them to other courses; |
| 3. | Build up a solid foundation of the necessary background for upper-level courses in electromagnetism and other physics courses in the curriculum; |
| 4. | Gain asense of relative importance of various physical quantities, and be able to make suitable approximations in mathematical derivations; |
| 5. | Gain a coherent picture of how the descriptions of various physical phenomena are unified by the laws of thermodynamics and Maxwell’s equations; |
| 6. | Gain an appreciation of the importance of thermodynamics and electromagnetism in physics, as well as their applications in the modern world. |

courses.subject: PHYS
courses.title: Quantitative Methods for Basic Physics
courses.description: This course provides an introduction to the various analytical techniques necessary for studying physics at university level. Topics include: vectors, rates of change and kinematics, methods for solving ordinary differential equations in mechanics and electric circuits, line integrals and multiple integrals in mechanics, partial differentiation and its applications in mechanics and thermodynamics, methods of vector calculus used in electromagnetism, and applications of infinite series and systems of linear equations in physics.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: MATH1010 or 1018 or its equivalents, or permission of instructor.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students will be able to:
1. demonstrate knowledge in basic mathematical methods in physics
2. formulate simple physical problems in mathematical form, and to solve them by mathematical technique, and to interpret the results physically
3. recognize the relative importance of different physical quantities, and hence take suitable approximations in mathematical derivations
4. identify how various mathematical methods can be combined coherently in describing physical systems and solving physical problems
5. appreciate the important role of mathematics in physics, as well as its applications in various areas in physical sciences
6. generalize the applications of the mathematical methods learnt in lectures to new situations
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Transcendental Functions of Complex Numbers
Logarithmic and exponential functions of complex numbers; complex trigonometric functions and hyperbolic functions

2. Vectors and Related Topics
Representations of vectors in different coordinate systems, including cylindrical coordinates and spherical coordinates; motion and trajectory in space; conic sections in polar coordinates; inversion, pseudovectors and pseudoscalars; index notations.

3. Applications of Calculus
Differentiation of vectors; central force field problems and solution of planetary motion; Lagrange multipliers; Dirac delta-function.

4. Infinite Series
Convergence and tests of convergence; power series and radius of convergence; Taylor series and approximations, Taylor polynomials for functions of two variables.

5. Ordinary Differential Equations - Methods and Applications
Physical examples in mechanics and electric circuits; the method of variation of parameters; the integrating factor method for homogeneous differential equations.

6. Matrices and Applications
Matrices, orthogonal matrix, determinants, eigenvalues and eigenvectors, Gaussian elimination, system of linear equations.

7. A quick review of partial differentiation
Partial derivatives, total differentials, chain rule, extremum values, Lagrange multipliers.

8. Multiple integrals
Double integrals in rectangular coordinates and polar coordinates; triple integrals in rectangular, cylindrical and spherical coordinates; Jacobian of transformation, surface area and integrals over a curved surface.

9. Vector calculus, line integral, surface integral and volume integral
Gradient, divergence and curl; vector operations in various coordinates; physical examples: field flux and divergence theorem, circulation and Stokes’s theorem, conservative fields.
courses.required_readings:
1. G Stephenson, ‘Mathematical Methods for Science Students’, 2nd ed, Prentice Hall, 1973 (Ref no. in library: QA37.S815 1973)
2. M L Boas, ‘Mathematical Methods in the Physical Sciences’, Wiley, 1983 (Ref no. in library: QA37.2.B698 1983)
3. R L Finney, M D Weir, F R Giordano, ‘Thomas’ Calculus’, 10th ed, Addison-Wesley, 2001 (Ref no. in library: QA303.T42 2001)
4. W E Boyce and R C DiPrima, ‘Elementary Differential Equations and Boundary Value Problems’, New York: J. Wiley, latest ed. (Ref no. in library: QA372.B72 1992)

courses.subject: PHYS
courses.title: Basic Computational Physics
courses.description: This course provides students with the basic knowledge of a few numerical methods and computer programming commonly used to solve problems in physics. Topics include: basic programming skills, interpolation, numerical integration of functions, numerical solution of ordinary differential equations and wave equations. There are computational laboratories for practice, demonstration and illustration of the subject matter. This course, together with PHYS3061 and 4061, provides basic, intermediate and advanced training on this important branch of computational physics. This fundamental course assumes no prior knowledge in computing.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken CSCI2800 / 1510 / 1520 / 1110 / 1120. Pre-requisite/Co-requisite: MATH1010 or 1018 or 1520 or its equivalents, or permission of instructor.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students will be able to:
1. perform elementary programming in C
2. demonstrate knowledge in basic numerical methods
3. employ numerical methods taught and C codes to solve basic physics problems
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction
Programing languages, program structures and version control.
2. C: Basic concepts
Variables, Expressions and statements, operators, Input/Output, compiling and running the first C program.
3. C: Control logic and iteration
If-else and switch statements, for, while, do…while, break and continue statements.
4. C: Functions and program structure
Basics of functions, scope rules, header files, block structure.
5. C: Arrays and pointers
Data structures and arrays, array definition and initialization. The concept of pointers, pointer assignment, dereferencing, indexing.
6. Numerical methods: Interpolation
Lagrange interpolation, Neville’s algorithm, Runge phenomenon, Chebyshev polynomials & nodes, Gibbs phenomenon.
7. Numerical methods: Integration of functions
Trapezoidal rule, Simpson’s rule, improper integrals, Gauss-Legendre integration.
8. Numerical methods: Ordinary differential equations
Euler method, Richardson extrapolation, Taylor method, Runge-Kutta method, boundary value problems, the shooting method.
9. Numerical methods (optional): Wave equations and Monte Carlo methods
Finite difference approximation to a PDE, Monte Carlo integration, importance sampling and hypothesis testing.

# Course Status: Core (2 units)

# 

# Course Content

| | **Topics** | **Highlights of Fundamental Concepts** |
| --- | --- | --- |
| 1 | Laboratory session on ‘Interference and diffraction of light’ | Wave nature of light, interference and diffraction. Use of lasers and photodetectors. |
| 2 | Laboratory session on ‘Half-life Physics: radioactivity’ | Radiation protection practices. Use of radioactive source, Geiger- Müller counter and smart timer. |
| 3 | Laboratory session on ‘Resistivity of metal and semiconductor’ | Conduction mechanisms in metal and semiconductor, and their temperature dependence; the four-point probe method. Use of digital multimeters and DC power supplies. |
| 4 | Laboratory session on ‘Resistance of tungsten filament in a lamp and black body radiation’ | Stefan-Boltzmann law, temperature dependence of tungsten resistivity at high temperature. Use of digital multimeters and DC power supplies. |
| 5 | Laboratory session on ‘Hall effect’ | The physics of Hall effect. Use of equipment including Hall probes, Gaussmeter and electromagnet. |
| 6 | Laboratory session on ‘Verification of Ampere’s Law’ | The integral form of Ampere’s law. Use of Helmholtz coils and Hall probes. |
| 7 | Laboratory session on ‘Charge-to-mass ratio of electron’ | Thomson’s experiment. Properties of electron, Lorentz force. Use of electron beam tube and Helmholtz coils. |
| 8 | Laboratory session on ‘Verification of Faraday's Law’ | The physics of Faraday's Law. Use of digital oscilloscope, coils and magnet. |
| 9 | Laboratory session on ‘Damped oscillator, forced oscillator and resonance’ | The physics of damped and forced harmonic oscillators, resonance, solutions of second order differential equation. Construction of a LRC circuits, use of digital oscilloscope, digital multimeter and LRZ meter. |
| 10 | Short test on use of equipment | |

| 1 | develop general considerations for the design of a scientific experiment |

| 2 | gain experience of using standard equipment to perform a measurement |
| 3 | acquire the ability of collecting, analyzing, handling and plotting of data, and estimation of errors by using Excel |
| 4 | know how to write a concise scientific report |
| 5 | acquire skills in problem solving, team work, computer usage, and planning a measurement |
| 6 | recognize the connection between theories and real-life measurements, and appreciate the principles taught in the lecture courses in introductory University Physics. |

# Course Description

| This course consists of several selected experiments with an aim to illustrate the principles taught in modern and quantum physics courses. Students will gain not only a deeper understanding of the principles behind the experiments, but also hands-on experience in hardware instrumentation, data acquisition, and report writing. Students are advised to take PHYS2711 before taking this course. Pre-requisite: PHYS1712 and PHYS2711. Demonstrate the ability to apply the principles and experimental techniques to familiar and unfamiliar situations, in a manner that would surpass the normal expectation at this level and standards that may be required at higher levels of study or research. Has the ability to express the objective, method and data analysis of the experimental study in the form of a report in a clear, cogent and possibly creative manner. A- : Demonstrate substantial command of principles and experimental techniques in the course required for attaining almost all the course learning outcomes. Demonstrate the ability to state and apply the principles and experimental techniques to familiar and some unfamiliar situations, in a manner that is logical and comprehensive. # Course Description

| The course covers the foundation of classical mechanics at the undergraduate level. Topics include: vectors, matrices and vector calculus; Newtonian mechanics of single particles; calculus of variations; Lagrangian and Hamiltonian mechanics; central force motion; dynamics of a system of particles; and moving coordinate systems. * *Course Status: Core**

# Course Content

| | Topics | **Highlights of Fundamental Concepts** |
| --- | --- | --- |
| 1. | Matrices, vectors and vector calculus | Rotation matrix. Definition of a scalar and a vector in terms of transformation matrix. Elementary scalar and vector operations. Differentiation and integration of vectors. (Thornton and Marion Chapter 1) |
| 2. | Newtonian mechanics of a single particle | Newton’s laws. Equation of motion. Conservation law. Energy. Solution of simple harmonic oscillators. Damped oscillations. Driven oscillators. Resonance. (Thornton and Marion Chapter 2,3) |
| 3. | Calculus of Variation | Euler’s equation. δ Notation. (Thornton and Marion Chapter 6) |
| 4. | Lagrangian and Hamiltonian mechanics | Degrees of freedom and generalized coordinates. Generalized momentum and force. Constraints (Optional). Lagrangian and Lagrange equations of motion. Hamiltonian and Hamilton’s equations of motion. Electromagnetic forces and velocity-dependent potentials. (Thornton and Marion Chapter 7) |
| 5. | Central force motion | Gravitational potential. Equations of orbits, inverse square force, eccentricity, Kepler's laws; two-body problem, reduced mass, hyperbolic orbits, Rutherford’s scattering, cross-section. (Thornton and Marion Chapter 5.2, Chapter 8) |
| 6. | Motion of a system of particles | Equations of motion, momentum, energy and their conservation laws, coupled harmonic oscillators and normal modes. (Thornton and Marion Chapter 9, Chapter 12) |
| 7. | Moving coordinate systems | Galilean transformation, accelerated reference frames, rotating frames, fictitious forces, motion on the surface of the earth, Larmor's theorem. (Thornton and Marion Chapter 10) |

# Learning Outcomes

By the end of the course, students will be able to:

| 1. | manage the procedures to solve the Newtonian dynamics of a particle in various standard situations, including systems with harmonic potentials, and central potentials. |
| --- | --- |
| 2. | state and apply the concept of Lagrangrian and Hamiltonian formalism of mechanics |
| 3. | describe and explain general features of motion of a system of particles, and motion in moving frames |

# Course Description

| This course provides an exposition of the central concepts and theoretical framework of non-relativistic quantum mechanics. Topics include: origins of quantum theory, Schrödinger equation, one-dimensional problems, harmonic oscillators, central potential problems, spins, and an overview of formalism in Dirac notation. Prerequisite: PHYS1122 or its equivalents, or permission of instructor. * *Course Status: Core course (3 units)**

# Course Content

| | Topics | **Highlights of Fundamental Concepts** |
| --- | --- | --- |
| 1. | Origins of quantum theory | Black body radiation, photo-electric effect, Compton effect, atomic spectra and Bohr model of the hydrogen atom, Stern-Gerlach experiment, De Broglie’s hypothesis, wave-particle duality. |
| 2. | Wave function and Schrödinger’s equation | Construction of the time-dependent Schrödinger’s equation, Statistical interpretation of the wave function, Operators, Expectation values and variance, Ehrenfest theorem. |
| 3. | One-dimensional problems | Stationary states and time-independent Schrödinger’s equation, Energy eigenvalues and eigenfunctions of infinite and finite square well systems, Transmission and reflection coefficients of scattering problems, Quantum tunneling, Spreading of a free Gaussian wave packet (optional). |
| 4. | Harmonic oscillators | Energy eigenfunctions in position space, applications of completeness and orthogonality of eigenfunctions, evolution of quantum superposition states. |
| 5. | Central potential problems | Schrödinger’s equation,Separation of variables and solution, Angular momentum and spherical harmonics, Hydrogen atom. |
| 6. | Spins | State vectors of a spin half particle, Dirac notation, Inner product, Orthogonality and completeness of bases vectors in the spin-half space, Pauli matrices and eigenvectors, Change of bases, Matrix form of the Hamiltonian operator and the Schrödinger equation, Spin precession in magnetic fields. |
| 7. | Formalism – An overview | Wave functions and state vectors, Inner product of two wave functions, Representation of wave functions as state vectors in orthonormal basis, Eigenvalues and eigenvectors of Hermitian operators, Axioms of quantum mechanics. |

# Learning Outcomes

By the end of the course, students will be able to:

| 1. | have a general understanding of how quantum theory was developed, and in particular appreciate how a new theory is developed when an existing theory fails to explain experimental observations |
| --- | --- |
| 2. | state and explain the basic concepts of wave-particle duality, uncertainty principle, and interpretation of quantum mechanical wave functions |
| 3. | solve the Schrödinger equation in various physical problems |
| 4. | demonstrate knowledge of the basic formulation of quantum mechanics, including the concept of state vectors and axioms of quantum mechanics |
| 5. | approach and tackle a given problem and apply appropriate mathematical and analytical skills in solving the problem |

# Course Description

| This course emphasizes the understanding of the fundamental concepts and basic theories of thermodynamics, and the analytical skills needed to analyze various thermodynamic systems. In addition to a classical approach to equilibrium thermodynamics and their applications, essential concepts in statistical physics including the relationship between microstates and entropy in an isolated system, the Boltzmann distribution, density of states, Fermi-Dirac and Bose-Einstein distributions will be discussed. Pre-requisites: PHYS2041 and 2051 or their equivalents, or permission of instructor. * *Course Status (Core, 3 units)**

# Course Content

| | Part I: on thermodynamics | Highlights of Fundamental Concepts |
| --- | --- | --- |
| 1. | The zeroth law of thermodynamics and thermodynamic variables | Thermodynamic systems, thermal equilibrium and the zeroth law, intensive and extensive variables, dilute gas and ideal gas, equation of state, ideal gas temperature scale. |
| 2. | Work and the first law of thermodynamics | Work in hydrostatic systems, expression of work in differential form; work and internal energy, heat and internal energy; quasi-static processes, which include the concepts of heat capacity, isothermal and adiabatic expansion/contraction. |
| 3. | The second law of thermodynamics | Heat engine, Kelvin-Planck and Clausius’ statement of the second law, reversible and irreversible processes, Carnot cycle and Carnot’s theorem. |
| 4. | Entropy | Entropy as a state function; thermodynamic temperature scale; entropy change for an irreversible process and a reversible process. |
| 5. | Thermodynamic potentials | Enthalpy, Helmholtz function, and Gibbs function, Maxwell’s relations; TdS equations, heat-capacity equations and internal energy equations. |
| 6. | Change of phase | The solid state, melting, evaporation, Clausius-Clapeyron equation, triple point and critical point. |

| | Part II: on statistical physics | Highlights of Fundamental Concepts |
| --- | --- | --- |
| 1. | Elementary kinetic theory of idea gas and Maxwell distribution of molecular speeds | A review on kinetic theory of gases, average kinetic energy and temperature, Maxwell distribution of molecular speeds, mean speed, root-mean-square speed, and the most probable speed, from distribution of molecular speeds to distribution of energy, the Maxwell-Boltzmann factor. |
| 2. | Microscopic interpretation of entropy | Microstates versus macrostates, all accessible microstates are equally probable and its validity, S=k ln W, selected application(s). |
| 2. | Equilibrium distributions | The Fermi-Dirac distribution, Bose-Einstein distribution, and the Maxwell-Boltzmann distribution as the most probable distributions under different conditions |
| 3. | Selected applications of Boltzmann distribution | Examples chosen, from but not restricted to, two-level system and its physical relevance, specific heat of a gas of molecules, law of equipartition of energy |
| 4. | Density of States | Density of single-particle states and its applications. |
| 5. | Introduction to Ideal Fermi Gas | Fermi energy, qualitative treatment on specific heat of electrons in metals, and other properties. |
| 6. | Introduction to Ideal Bose Gas | Possibility of Bose-Einstein condensation and its physical relevance. |

# Learning Outcomes

By the end of the course, students will be able to:

| 1. | describe and explain the fundamental concepts of thermodynamics, in particular, the concepts temperature, heat, entropy and free energies. |
| --- | --- |
| 2. | acquire a microscopic viewpoint of thermodynamics |
| 3. | appreciate the key steps in the development of thermodynamics and statistical physics. |
| 4. | apply the concepts in thermal and statistical physics to different systems. |
| 5. | distinguish idealized systems (e.g, ideal gas) from real systems. |
| 6. | solve problems in thermal and statistical physics using appropriate mathematical and numerical skills. |

| 7. | Electromagnetic waves – An introduction | EM wave equations in the vacuum, Monochromatic plane wave solution in complex notation, Energy and momentum in EM waves, EM waves in linear media, reflection and transmission of EM waves at normal incidence, Transmission and absorption of EM waves in conducting media, Dipole radiation, Energy flux of EM radiation. |

courses.title: Methods in Theoretical Physics I
courses.description: This course provides a survey of various analytical techniques commonly used to solve problems in theoretical physics. The following physical problems are used as examples: heat conduction, vibrating strings and membranes, waves and electrostatics. Students are advised to take the introductory calculus-based physics courses: PHYS1111 or 1113, 1122, 2041 or their equivalents before taking this course.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: PHYS2051 or MATH2020 or their equivalents, or permission of the instructor.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students will be able to:
1. demonstrate knowledge of the mathematical tools taught necessary for future studies in physics.
2. manage the techniques of analyzing and expressing a physical problem in a mathematical way, and then solving it.
courses.course_syllabus:
* *1. Problems in heat conduction**
Derivation of the diffusion equation. Solution by separation of variables. Sturm-Liouville problem in general, orthogonality and completeness of eigenfunctions.

* *2. Vibrating string and circular membrane; one-dimensional wave equation**
Derivation of the one-dimensional wave equation; motion of homogeneous vibrating string with fixed or free ends.
Initial-value problem of the one-dimensional wave equation on the whole real line; general solution and the d’ Alembert solution.
Radially symmetric vibration of a circular membrane: series solution of Bessel’s differential equation, introduction to Bessel functions.

* *3. Problems in Electrostatics**
Poisson’s equation and Laplace’s equation in electrostatics and steady-state heat conduction. Solution of two- and three-dimensional Laplace’s equation in rectangular coordinates with various boundary conditions.
Laplace’s equation in cylindrical coordinates.
Laplace’s equation in spherical coordinates: the general solution with azimuthal symmetry, series solution of Legendre’s differential equation, Legendre polynomials and spherical harmonics.

* *4. Eigenfunction expansion and Laplace and Fourier transforms**
Eigenfunction expansion for solving nonhomogeneous partial differential equations.
Laplace transform and its applications to problems in heat conduction and vibrating string.
Fourier series and Fourier transform, solution of heat conduction in infinite rod and one-dimensional wave equation by Fourier transform.

courses.description:
This is a project-oriented course on computer simulation, emphasizing the setting up of physical models, the development of algorithms for the models, data analysis and graphical techniques. The basic usage of generative AI will be introduced, and students will be expected to practice the AI tools in computer simulation. Topics include: the cooling problem, single and many particle dynamics, chaotic dynamics, random processes, wave phenomena, and electrostatic problems. There are computational laboratories for practice, demonstration and illustration of the subject matter. Students are expected to have a solid background in the introductory calculus-based physics courses: PHYS1111, 1122, 2041 and first-year mathematics course: MATH1010, and have written working computer programs before taking this course.
Students are advised to seek prior advice from the instructor before enrolment.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students will be able to:

1. master various means of ‘do physics’ with the computer.
2. gain deeper understanding of the physics learned in other courses from different angle, and experience how physics can be applied in a much broader context than it was discussed in the traditional physics undergraduate curriculum.
3. gain experience on ‘discover’ physics in a way similar to how physicists learn in the context of research.
4. manage basic numerical methods and apply them to solve physics problems.
5. develop structured programming in the context of doing science.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Cooling problem
Euler algorithm for solving first-order differential equations.
2. Single particle dynamics
Newton 's equations of motion, numerical simulation of trajectories and planet motion., higher-order algorithms, phase space analysis, simple graphics.
3. Coupled oscillators and normal modes
Equation of motion for coupled oscillators, boundary conditions, dispersion relation and normal modes. Fourier analysis.
4. Wave phenomena
Derivation of linear wave equation by taking limit of a linear chain of coupled oscillators, interference, diffraction and polarization. Nonlinear oscillator and FPU problem.
5. Chaotic dynamics
Study of simple deterministic nonlinear models which exhibit complex patterns of behaviour e.g. logistic map.
6. Random Process
Particle in a box, random number generator, Monte Carlo simulation and algorithms. Random walks, simulation of self-avoiding walk, diffusion equation.
7. Many particle dynamics
Simulation of dynamical behaviour of many particle systems, measurements of thermodynamic quantities and simple transport properties.
8. Electromagnetism
Relaxation method and random walk method for solving Laplace's and Poisson’s equations. Finite difference time domain solution of Maxwell equations.
9. Seven computational laboratories

* Simulating particle motion
* Few body problem
* Normal modes and wave motion
* Molecular dynamics simulation
* Electric field and electric potential
* Random processes
* Monte Carlo method

2. Harvey Gould and Jan Tobochnik, ‘An Introduction to Computer Simulation Methods, Applications to Physical Systems’, Second edition 1996 Addison-Wesley (Ref no. in library: QC52 .G68 1996)
3. Nancy Blachman and Colin P. Williams: Mathematica: A Practical Approach, second edition 1999 Prentice-Hall (Ref no. in library: QA76.95 .B53 1999)
4. Samuel S M Wong: Computational Methods in Physics and Engineering 1997 World-Scientific (Ref no. in library: QC52 .W66 1997)

# Course Content

| | Topics | **Highlights of Fundamental Concepts** |
| --- | --- | --- |
| 1. | Basic concepts in thermodynamics and physical chemistry | Free energy, entropy, chemical potential, osmotic pressure, chemical equilibrium, solution thermodynamics (Doi Chapter 1,2) |
| 2. | Molecular interactions | van der Waals interaction; electrostatics of biomolecules; electrostatic interaction between colloids and molecules; depletion force (Doi Chapter 2; Jones Chapter 2) |
| 3. | Molecules in motion | Diffusion; reaction kinetics; enzymatic reactions; molecular switching and allosteric regulation; coupling between chemical reactions and diffusion process (Nelson Chapters 3,4; Doi Chapter 6) |
| 4. | Materials in motion | Basic concepts in continuum mechanics/biomechanics and rheology, viscosity, viscoelastic behavior of fluids, low Reynolds hydrodynamics (Doi Chapter 3,9; Phillips Chapters 10, 11; Jones Chapter 5; Nelson Chapter 5) |

| 6. | Diffusion in living processes | Fundamental limit on cell size; Nernst potential across membranes; chemical signaling of bacteria and general gradient sensing (Nelson Chapters 4,11; Phillips Chapter 13,14) |
| 7. | Self-assembly of biomolecules and molecular machines | Molecular self-assembly driven by entropic force; Molecular motors that couple diffusion, free energy transduction and enzymatic reactions (Nelson Chapters 8,9,10; Phillips Chapter 14) |
| 8. | Energetics and electrical behavior of cells | Energy metabolism and chemiosmosis; ion channels and action potentials; nerve impulse (Nelson Chapters 11,12) |
| 9. | Dynamics in the cell | Dynamics of gene and protein regulatory networks; robustness and adaptation of regulatory networks; genetic oscillator (Phillips Chapter 19) |
| 10. | Mechanics and motile behavior of cells | Mechanical response of cells; mechanisms of self-propulsion in bacterial and eukaryotic cells (Phillips Chapters 10,11,12; Nelson Chapter 5) |

# Course Description

| This course provides an introduction to electronic circuits commonly used in experimental physics. It aims at providing hands-on experience on what electronic components and circuits can do. Topics include: circuit analysis, diode circuits, rectifying circuits, transistors, operational amplifiers, and logic circuits. Each topic begins with an overview of the fundamentals, followed by laboratory exercises for practicing the concepts. The course ends with a short project. The course is essential for performing experimental works in senior projects and postgraduate studies. The course assumes no prior experience in electronics.(Not for students who have taken ELEG2202) Pre-requisite: PHYS2041 and PHYS2711, or permission of the instructor. Grade Descriptor A : Demonstrate thorough mastery of principles and subject matter in the course required for attaining all the course learning outcomes. Demonstrate the ability to apply the principles or subject matter to familiar and unfamiliar situations, in a manner that would surpass the normal expectation at this level and standards that may be required at higher levels of study or research. Has the ability to express the knowledge or synthesis of ideas in a clear and cogent manner. A- : Demonstrate substantial command of principles and subject matter in the course required for attaining almost all the course learning outcomes. Demonstrate the ability to state and apply the principles or subject matter to familiar and some unfamiliar situations, in a manner that is logical and comprehensive. Has the ability to express the knowledge or application with clarity and accuracy. B : Demonstrate general and sufficient command of principles and subject matter in the course required for attaining most of the course learning outcomes. Demonstrate the ability to state and apply the principles or subject matter accurately to most (but not necessarily all) familiar and standard situations, in a manner that is logical and persuasive. Demonstrate the ability to state and apply the principles or subject matter to most (but not necessarily all) familiar and standard situations, but with occasional errors and/or in a manner that is fragmented. Has the ability to express the separate pieces of knowledge in an unambiguous way. D : Demonstrate partial command of principles and subject matter in the course required for attaining some of the course learning outcomes. Demonstrate the ability to state and apply the principles or subject matter to some simple situations only. Has the ability to state the knowledge or application in simple terms. # Course Content

| | Topics | **Highlights of Fundamental Concepts** |
| --- | --- | --- |
| 1. | Circuit analysis | Ohm’s law. Kirchoff's voltage and current laws |
| 2. | Resistors, capacitors, and diodes | Resistors, Color Code, Power Rating. RC circuits. Transient behaviors. RC filters. P-n junction. Forward and backward biases. IV characteristics of diodes. |
| 3. | Switches, Rectifiers and Function Generators | Rectifying circuits. Half and full wave rectifiers. Bridge rectifier network. Zener diode. Relays. |
| 4. | Transistors | Bipolar and FET transistors. Common-base and common-emitter circuits. Amplifier. Equivalent circuits. Transistors as switches. |
| 5. | Operational amplifier (op-amp) circuits | Ideal op-amps. Equivalent circuit models. Signal amplifiers. Various amplifiers. |
| 6. | Logic circuits | Comparators. Flip flops. Counters and clocks. |
| 7. | Project | Design and construct a simple circuit for a defined application |

| 1. | analyze and read simple circuits encountered in experimental physics. |

courses.title: Radio Observational Astronomy
courses.description: The course aims to provide students with a flavor of radio astronomy, including instrumentation and hands-on experience in data acquisition and analysis. The major types of telescopes (single-dish telescopes and interferometers), instrumentation (bolometers and heterodyne receivers), and observational strategies will be surveyed, along with examples of celestial objects targeted by each technique. PHYS3430 and PHYS3440 are independent courses from each other.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: PHYS2711.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students will be able to:

1. Understand the methodologies (instruments and observation methods) and targets of radio astronomy.
2. Have a basic understanding of radio astronomy data formats and analysis.
3. Perform basic observations (total intensity and spectra) and data analysis for radio astronomy.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Types of radio emissions
Thermal, line, bremsstrahlung, and synchrotron radiation.

2. The universe probed by radio emissions
Cosmic background radiation, galaxies, molecular clouds, and black hole vicinities.

3. Bolometers and heterodyne receivers
Operation principles of the two types of detectors.

4. Single-dish radio telescopes and interferometers
Operation principles of the two types of telescopes.

5. Observations with a single-dish radio telescope
Observing the Sun and Milky Way with a 2-meter radio telescope, *TeleFoam*, an “open-hood” telescope for educational purposes.

6. Lab astronomy
Through numerical simulations and particle image velocimetry (PIV), students first visualize the phenomena of gas differential rotation and turbulence. Subsequently, we guide them through understanding how these phenomena are projected onto the sky plane and explain which parameters can be detected by bolometers and heterodyne receivers, respectively, to generate various types of data.

7. Data analysis
Following 6, the methodologies for analyzing various data types will be introduced.

courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students will be able to:

1. List different types of targets of astronomical observations, their radiation mechanisms, and how they can be observed.
2. Describe the practical challenges of optical observations posed by the properties of light, the atmosphere, the interstellar medium, and the limitations of current technologies, etc.
3. Explain the working principles of different types of telescopes, instruments, and detectors.
4. Collect, calibrate, and analyze data taken through astronomical observations.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Motivation and targets of observations
Motivation, astronomical objects to observe, and their radiation mechanisms.

2. Practical challenges of optical observations
The moving sky, effects of the atmosphere, natural and artificial light pollution, limits of observations.

3. Optical telescopes and instrumentations
Types of telescopes and mounts, angular resolution, plate scale, optical aberrations, imaging and spectroscopy instrumentations.

4. CCD/CMOS Detectors and calibration
CCD, CMOS, bias, read noise, dark current, gain, flat fielding, method to measure these properties.

5. Photometry
Magnitude system, filters, background subtraction, aperture photometry, curve of growth, SNR equation, PSF photometry, and calibration.

* 6.* Spectroscopy
Slit spectroscopy, fiber spectroscopy, integral field spectroscopy, spectral extraction, wavelength and flux calibration.

7. Hands-on data acquisition and analysis
Conducted in parallel with topics 4-6, practice the methods on data collection, processing, and analysis.
courses.required_readings:
1. Observational Astronomy, 2nd Edition, by D. Scott Birney, Guillermo Gonzalez, & David Oesper. (Online access through CUHK library)
2. Handbook of CCD Astronomy, 2nd Edition, by Steve B. Howell. (Online access through CUHK library)

courses.description: This is an advanced undergraduate course on classical mechanics. The course covers waves in mechanical systems, fluid mechanics, special theory of relativity, and one topic from either nonlinear mechanics or dynamics of rigid bodies.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: PHYS3051 or its equivalents, or permission of the instructor.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students will be able to:
1. provide a coherent picture of the physics of waves in mechanical systems, including the mathematical treatment of wave equations and general properties of solutions.
2. state and describe the basic theorems and applications in fluid mechanics.
3. demonstrate knowledge of relativistic effects and their theoretical treatment.
4. solve mechanics problems of selected topics.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Waves
Wave equation of a vibrating string. Boundary conditions, normal modes of vibration and energy.
Superposition. Fourier series solution of a vibrating strings. Phase velocity and group velocity. General solution of the wave equation. Behavior of waves at a junction. Impedance and impedance matching. Waves in two and three dimensions. Normal modes of rectangular box. Sound waves. Power of waves. Fourier transformation analysis (optional), wave packets and uncertainty relation (optional). (Thornton and Marion Chapter 13; Crawford Chapters 2, 4, 6)

2. Fluid mechanics
Equation of continuity; equations of motion for an ideal fluid. Hydrostatics. Rotational and irrotational flows. Bernoulli’s theorem and its applications. Sound waves. Simple laminar flows of viscous fluids. Poseuille's formula. Surface tension. Navier-Stokes equation. (Arya Chapter 15, Symon Chapter 8)
Equation of continuity; equations of motion for an ideal fluid. Hydrostatics. Rotational and irrotational flows. Bernoulli’s theorem and its applications. Sound waves. Simple laminar flows of viscous fluids. Poseuille's formula. Surface tension. Navier-Stokes equation. (Arya Chapter 15, Symon Chapter 8)

3. Special theory of relativity
Basic postulates, Lorentz transformation, Lorentz contraction and time dilation, addition of velocities, twin paradox, relativistic equations of motion of a particle, relativistic momentum and energy and their applications. Four-vector formalism. (Marion Chapter 14)

4. One of the following topics up to the choice of the instructor:
(4a) Nonlinear mechanics
Anharmonic oscillator and Duffing’s equation, sine-Gordon equation and solitons. (Thornton and Marion Chapter 4, Barger and Olsson, Chapter 11)
(4b) Elementary Dynamics of rigid bodies
Angular momentum and kinetic energy, moment of inertia, dynamics of rigid body in a plane, combined rotational and translational motion, Euler's equations (Thornton and Marion Chapter 11 )
courses.required_readings:
1. S T Thornton and J B Marion, “Classical Dynamics of Particles & Systems”, 5th ed., Thomson, 2004. (Ref no. in library: QA845.M38 2004)
2. A P French, “Vibrations and Waves” (Rev ed), Norton, 1966. (Ref no. in library: QC235.F74 1971)
3. F S Crawford, “Waves”, Berkeley Physics Course, Vol. 3, McGraw-Hill, 1968. (Ref no. in library: QC21 B4445 v.3)
4. K R Symon, “Mechanics”, 3rd ed, Addison-Wesley, 1971. (Ref no. in library: QC125.S98 1971)
5. V Barger and M Olsson, “Classical Mechanics: A Modern Perspective”. McGraw-Hill 2nd ed., 1995. (Ref no. in library: QA805. B287 1995)
6. A P Ayra, “Introduction to Classical Mechanics”, 2nd ed. Benjamin Cummings, 1997 (Ref no. in library: QC125.2.A79)

* *Course Status: Elective (3 units)**

# Course Content

| | Topics | **Highlights of Fundamental Concepts** |
| --- | --- | --- |
| 1. | Formalism of quantum mechanics | Postulates in quantum mechanics. State vectors and observables. Matrix representation of operators. Unitary transformation and change of basis. Measurement and probability interpretation. Uncertainty relations. Quantum dynamics. Schrodinger picture and Heisenberg picture. |
| 2. | Operator methods in a harmonic oscillator | Creation and annihilation operators. Algebraic solution of energy eigenvalues and eigenvectors. Oscillator under a static force, translational transformation, and momentum operator. Coherent states.Driven quantum harmonic oscillators (optional). Squeezed states (optional). Coupled oscillators (optional). |
| 3. | Angular momentum | Rotational operation and orbital angular momentum. Fundamental commutation relations of angular momentum operators. Eigenvalues and eigenvectors of angular momentum operators. Rotational symmetry and conservation of angular momentum. Spin-1/2, two-level systems and Pauli matrices. Addition of angular momenta (optional) |
| 4. | Approximation methods in stationary systems | Non-degenerate and degenerate perturbation theory. Variation method (optional). WKB method (optional). |
| 5. | Approximation methods in non-stationary systems | Time-dependent perturbation theory. Fermi golden rule. Adiabatic approximation. Berry’s phase. |
| 6. | Quantum entanglement (optional) | Entangled states and disentangled states. Projective measurements on bipartite systems. Entanglemen f pure states. Bell’s inequality. Applications of quantum entanglement. |

# Learning Outcomes

By the end of the course, students will be able to:

| 1. | state and describe the formalism of non-relativistic quantum mechanics in terms of Dirac notations. |
| --- | --- |
| 2. | manage basic operator algebra in quantum mechanics, and to apply them to harmonic oscillator systems and angular momentum problems |
| 3. | manage approximation concepts and methods in quantum mechanics, and apply them to study various quantum systems. |

# PHYS 4031 Statistical Mechanics

# Course Description

| This course provides an introduction to equilibrium statistical mechanics of classical and quantum systems via the theory of ensembles. Topics include: thermodynamic potentials, review on microcanonical ensemble, canonical ensemble, open systems and grand canonical ensemble, Bose-Einstein and Fermi-Dirac statistics and their applications, properties of ideal quantum gases. Elementary thermodynamics and statistical physics of phase transformation and transport phenomena will also be discussed. Students are advised to take PHYS3031 or its equivalents before taking this course. Pre-requisites: PHYS2041 and 2051 or their equivalents, or permission of instructor.
