Has the ability to express the knowledge or application with clarity and accuracy. B : Demonstrate general and sufficient command of principles and subject matter in the course required for attaining most of the course learning outcomes. Demonstrate the ability to state and apply the principles or subject matter accurately to most (but not necessarily all) familiar and standard situations, in a manner that is logical and persuasive. Has the ability to express the knowledge or application in a satisfactory and unambiguous way. Demonstrate the ability to state and apply the principles or subject matter to most (but not necessarily all) familiar and standard situations, but with occasional errors and/or in a manner that is fragmented. Has the ability to express the separate pieces of knowledge in an unambiguous way. D : Demonstrate partial command of principles and subject matter in the course required for attaining some of the course learning outcomes. Demonstrate the ability to state and apply the principles or subject matter to some simple situations only. Has the ability to state the knowledge or application in simple terms. F : Demonstrate little or no evidence of command of principles and subject matter in the course required for attaining the course learning outcomes, OR failure to meet specified assessment requirements. |
| --- |

* *Course Status: Elective (3 units)**

# Course Content

| | Topics | **Highlights of Fundamental Concepts** |
| --- | --- | --- |
| 1. | What is statistical mechanics? And a short review of thermodynamics. | To know what to be learnt. Recap key relations in thermodynamics |
| 2. | Types of equilibrium systems, microstates, macrostates, and distributions. | Microstates. Recap methods of counting. |
| 3. | The fundamental postulate of equal a priori probabilities for microstates in an isolated system in equilibrium. Microcanonical ensemble. | Idea of ensemble average. Stirling’s approximation. Evaluations of other thermodynamic quantities. Classical ideal gas and validity of results. Volume of high-dimensional sphere. Worked Examples. Gibbs’ entropy formula. |
| 4. | Boltzmann distribution. Canonical ensemble. Partition function and Helmholtz free energy. | Derivation. Mean energy. Partition function. Calculations using the partition function. Energy Fluctuations. Examples: Two-level systems, paramagnetism, harmonic oscillators, Einstein’s and Debye’s models of solids, rotational partition function. Doing sums . |
| 5. | Examples of classical statistical mechanics. | Classical ideal gas. Validity of classical description, thermal de Broglie wavelength. Equipartition theorem. Examples: Harmonic oscillators. Maxwell’s distribution of molecular speeds, diatomic gas, etc. Gaussian integrals.Classical non-ideal gas (optional) as an example of interacting systems. |
| 6. | Short review on Bose-Einstein and Fermi-Dirac distributions | (Covered in PHYS3031) The most probable distribution. Bose-Einstein and Fermi-Dirac distributions as the most probable distributions for non-interacting indistinguishable particles, physical meaning, Maxwell-Boltzmann distribution as classical limit. Method of Lagrange multipliers. |
| 7. | Single-particle states: Non-interacting or weakly interacting systems. Density of single-particle states. | Fitting waves into a confined space, k-space, turning sum over single-particle states into integrals over k, density of single-particle states. |
| 8. | Open systems, Gibbs distribution, chemical potential. Grand partition function. Grand canonical ensemble. | Derivation. Grand partition function and grand potential. Calculation of other thermodynamic quantities. Fluctuations. Examples: Ideal quantum gases with Fermi-Dirac and Bose-Einstein distributions re-derived. |
| 9. | Applications of Fermi-Dirac statistics. | Physics of ideal Fermi gas. Zero-temperature and low-temperature properties. Examples may include degenerate electron gas (metals, white dwarfs), electronic specific heat of metals, degenerate neutron gas (neutron stars). High-temperature correction to ideal gas law. Doing integrals involving the FD function. |
| 10. | Applications of Bose-Einstein statistics. | Physics of ideal Bose gas. Bose-Einstein condensation and its realization. The thermal (blackbody) radiation may be presented as an optional example. |
| 11. | Ferromagnetism as an introduction to phase transitions | Ferromagnetism as an example of interacting systems. Mean field approximation to Ising model. An introduction to Landau theory of second order phase transitions. (Optional): 1D Ising model. |
| 12. | Introduction to non-equilibrium statistical mechanics (Optional) | Mean free path, transport coefficients. |

# Learning Outcomes

By the end of the course, students will be able to:

| 1. | appreciate the connection between statistical mechanics and thermodynamics and to realize that many results in statistical physics come from the same fundamental postulate |
| --- | --- |
| 2. | state and describe the ensemble theories in statistical mechanics |
| 3. | carry out calculations of thermodynamic properties for typical (mostly non-interacting) physical systems using ensemble theories |
| 4. | make connections to concepts acquired in other physics courses, e.g. thermodynamics, quantum mechanics, solid state physics and astrophysics |
| 5. | apply statistical mechanics to ideal Fermi gas and ideal Bose gas, and to relate results to physical problems |
| 6. | manage mathematical skills related to counting, Stirling’s formula, Gaussian integrals, summations, method of Lagrange multipliers, and integrals involving Fermi-Dirac and Bose-Einstein distributions |
| 7. | manage the basic principles for further studies on the statistical mechanics of interesting systems |

courses.subject: PHYS
courses.title: Solid State Physics
courses.description: This core course aims at providing students with the essential concepts of solid state physics and an understanding of the properties of matter. The properties of solids are discussed using skills and concepts acquired in the fundamental subjects in physics. The course thus also serves to illustrate how physical concepts can be applied to explain the various properties of solids. Topics include: crystal lattices and structures, wave diffraction and reciprocal lattice, lattice vibrations, thermal properties of insulators, metallic behavior and free electron gas, energy bands, semiconductor physics and devices, magnetic properties, dielectric properties, and superconductivity. This is a capstone core course (subject matter) normally taken in final year of study. Students are also recommended to take PHYS3022 before taking this course.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite/Co-requisite: PHYS3021 or its equivalents, or permission of instructor.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students will be able to:
1. describe and explain the basic physical properties of crystalline solids and the underlying physics
2. illustrate how physics works in the context of solids
3. employ the knowledge for going deeper into the subject in the future and for self-learning of other topics not covered in the course
4. appreciate the far-reaching contributions of physics to mankind, within the context of solid state physics
5. make use of qualitative arguments and physical concepts (developed in different fundamental subjects) to the understand of the properties of solids
6. gain experience on peer-learning
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Heat capacity of solids
Einstein and Debye’s calculations, Born-von Karman boundary condition (SHS 2; CK 5; JDL 7.5)

2. Metallic behavior and free electron gas
How far one can get in explaining metallic behavior using a free-electron model? Fermi energy, Fermi wavevector, density of states, plasma
frequency (comparison with experiment), heat capacity, conductivity, optical properties, Hall effect, thermal conductivity (SHS 3, 4; JDL 1, 2, 12; CK 6, HPM 6)

3. Crystal Structures
Crystalline periodicity, Bravais lattices, description of crystal structures, some typical crystal structures, (optical: quasicrystals), a short review on crystal binding (SHS 12, 6; CK 1, 3; JDL 10; HPM 1, 2)

4. Wave diffraction and the reciprocal lattice
Bragg law, reciprocal lattices, diffraction of waves by crystals (Laue condition), structure factor, brief introduction to experimental techniques (SHS 13, 14; CK 2; HPM 3; JDL 4.4)

5. Lattice vibrations
Heat capacity of insulators, Einstein model and its inadequacy, normal modes, monatomic linear chain, diatomic linear chain, atomic vibrations in three dimensions (brief) , Brillouin zones, phonon dispersion relations, relation to speed of sound (elastic waves in solids), idea of phonons (the notion of describing low-energy excitations of a many-body system by fictitious (quasi) particles), counting modes (density of states), Debye model, anharmonic effects (thermal expansion and thermal conductivity of insulators), inelastic neutron scattering (SHS 9,10; JDL 7; CK 4; HPM 5);

6. Energy bands
Periodic potentials, electron states in crystals, nearly free electrons, tightly bounded electrons, band structure, semi-classical equation of motion of Bloch electrons, conductor, semiconductor and insulator (SHS 15, 16; JDL 11, 13, 14; CK 7, (part of)9; HPM 7) (Optional/Brief: photonic crystals, inadequacy of single-electron approaches)

7. Basic semiconductor physics and devices
Typical band structure, band gap, effective mass, holes, intrinsic behavior and extrinsic behaviour (SHS 17; JDL 15, CK 8, HPM 10), p-n junction and applications (I-V curve, LED, laser, photodetector, (brief) transistors) (SHS 18; JDL 16; HMP 10), (brief) exciton

8. Magnetic properties
Diamagnetism, paramagnetism, spontaneous magnetization and ferromagnetism (SHS 19, 20; JDL 5; CK 11, 12; HPM 11)

9. Dielectric Media
Polarization of dielectrics, local electric field, Clausius-Mossotti formula, frequency dependence of dielectric constant, (brief) ferroelectrics (JDL 3, 4; HMP 12; CK 16)

10. Superconductivity
The phenomena of superconductivity; qualitative discussion of Cooper pair and BCS theory; Electrodynamics of superconductors, London equations (JDL 6, CK 10, HPM 13)
courses.required_readings:
1. Detailed Class Notes (Available at course webpage)
2. S. H. Simon, “The Oxford Solid State Basics”
3. C. Kittel, "Introduction to Solid State Physics" (8th edition) (Ref no. in library: QC176.K5 2005)
4. J. Richard Christman, "Fundamentals of solid state physics" (Ref no. in library: QC176.C47)
5. J. R. Hook and H.E. Hall, "Solid state physics" (Ref no. in library: QC176.H66 1991)
6. J. Richard Christman, "Fundamentals of solid state physics", 2nd ed, Chichester; New York: Wiley, 1991 (Ref no. in library: QC176.C47)
7. Harald Ibach, Hans Luth; [translated by A. Lahee], "Solid-state physics: An introduction to theory and experiment" (Ref no. in library: QC176.I2313)
8. Neil W. Ashcroft and N. David Mermin, "Solid state physics" (Ref no. in library: QC176.A83)
9. Madelung, O. (Otfried), "Introduction to solid-state theory" (Ref no. in library: QC176.M2313 1978)

courses.description: Unlike a course in computer science or programming, this course is intended to provide a solid training in the computational techniques for the analysis and modelling of physical systems. It focuses specifically on methods for solving various physics problems. Topics include: basic numerical methods, numerical methods in linear algebra, numerical methods for ordinary and partial differential equations in physics, brief introduction to machine learning in physics.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken PHYS5160. Pre-requisite: PHYS2061 or its equivalents, or permission of instructor.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. To learn through direct experience the use of modern computers in thinking creatively and solving problems in physical science.
2. To advance the development and organization of thinking about physical systems in a manner compatible with advanced computational analysis.
3. To use the graphical capabilities of modern computers to visualize numerical solutions in highly interpretable forms.
4. To instill attitudes of independence and organization, which are essential for mastery of complex systems.
5. To use programming to deepen the understanding of physical systems.
6. To understand why hard work and even properly functioning and powerful software and hardware do not guarantee meaningful results. To always be aware that there are limits to the accuracy possible with finite machines and to the applicability of our models.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Basic numerical methods
Briefly reviewed: Interpolations and approximations. Differentiation and integration. Zeros and extrema of a single-variable function.
2. Numerical methods in linear algebra
Briefly reviewed: Matrices in physics, basic matrix operations, linear equation systems, eigenvalue problems, optimization.
3. Ordinary differential equations
Main topic and project. Ordinary differential equations in physics, e.g. Newton's equation of motion. Atomic scale simulation
4. Partial differential equations
Briefly reviewed: Partial differential equations in physics, e.g., diffusion.
5. Monte Carlo simulation

courses.description: This course provides an introduction to the physical principles in meteorology, weather observation and forecasting. Topics include: physics of fluids; dynamic meteorology; atmospheric thermodynamics; atmospheric physics (cloud and lightning); weather systems and phenomena; weather observation, analysis and forecasting; climate change. Trips to Hong Kong Observatory headquarters/ outstations will be arranged to acquaint students with the operation of meteorological instruments and the real-life practice of weather analysis and forecasting.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Pre-requisite: PHYS3011.
Students who have taken course on vector calculus-based physics or their equivalents may also seek course teacher's permission to register in the course.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students will be able to:
1. comprehensively understand the major physical principles underlying meteorology
2. apply the basic knowledge of physics to obtain better appreciation of various weather systems and phenomena affecting our daily life
3. manage the basic operational principles of weather observation, analysis and forecasting
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Physics of Fluids of the Atmosphere
Overview of the basic concepts and equations of the atmosphere as a thin layer of fluid covering the earth, including: the composition of the Atmosphere, Navier-Stokes Equation in a rotating frame, Coriolis force, ideal gas law, hydrostatic equation, shallow water equation, vorticity and divergence.

2. Weather Systems and Phenomena
Low and high pressure systems, thunderstorm, tropical cyclone, tornado

3. Dynamic Meteorology
Geostrophic and Gradient winds, geopotental height and thickness, conservation laws, waves in the Atmosphere, including Rossby wave, gravity wave, shallow water wave, acoustic wave.

4. Atmospheric Thermodynamics
Radiation laws and energy balance in the Atmosphere, thermodynamics of dry air, thermodynamic of moist air, stabilities of the Atmosphere, thermodynamic diagrams.

5. Atmospheric Physics
Cloud physics and atmospheric electricity.

6. Weather Observations
Physical principles of the meteorological instruments, particularly remote sensing equipment such as weather radar and meteorological satellite.

7. Weather Analysis and Forecasting
Surface chart, upper-air analysis and Tephigram analysis. Modern forecasting techniques, Numerical Weather Prediction, chaos and predictability

courses.description: This course provides an introduction to modern astronomy and cosmology. Topics include: star formation and pre-main sequence evolution, main sequence stars, post-main sequence evolution: red giants, white dwarfs, supernovae, neutron stars and black holes. Students should have basic knowledge in mechanics, quantum mechanics and thermal physics (PHYS3011, 3021, 3031) before taking this course. Students are advised to seek prior advice from the instructor before enrolment.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students will be able to:
1. describe and explain the basic concepts of galactic/stellar formation and evolution, compact objects, and cosmology
2. demonstrate the ability to further pursue these topics in depth
3. apply the knowledge acquired from other courses (eg, quantum physics, statistical mechanics, electromagnetism etc) to study various astrophysical systems
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Observational facts
CMBR, galactic “great walls”, galactic structures, molecular clouds, protostellar discs, stellar outflows, H-R diagram, planetary system, astronomical instrumentation.

2. Cosmology
Cosmological principle, expansion of the universe, cosmological models, Cosmic microwave background, cosmic acceleration, Inflation.

3. Galaxy formation
“The great walls”, galaxy types and structures, density wave, galactic shearing motion, rotational curves, galactic magnetic field.

4. Molecular clouds
Cloud formation, cloud fragmentation, super-/sub-Alfvenic turbulence, magnetic fields & virial equilibrium, log-normal cloud column density distribution, star formation efficiency and rate

5. Stellar cluster and massive stars formation
Initial mass function, competitive accretion, stellar feedback, radiation pressure

6. Protostellar discs and out flows
α-Disc Model, magneto-rotational instability, magnetic-braking catastrophe, ambipolar diffusion, Ohmic diffusion, Hall effect, stellar outflows, bipolar jets, proto-planetary discs, planetary formation.

7. Stellar evolution
Main-sequence evolution, the Schronberg-Chandrasekhar limit, late stages of stellar evolution, stellar pulsations, core-collapse supernovae.

8. Compact stars & black holes
White dwarfs, the Chandrasekhar limit, cooling of white dwarfs, neutron stars, pulsars, black holes

Lenses, mirrors, prisms, fiber optics, aberrations, introduction to ray tracing, optical systems

Nature of polarization, birefringence, polarizers and retarders, applications of polarization

Examples of two-beam interference. Stokes relations. Multiple-beam interference. Theories and applications of optical interferometers. Resonators.

5. Diffraction
General concepts of diffraction. Examples of Fraunhofer and Fresnel diffraction. Diffraction grating and its applications.

6. Modern optics (Optional)
Coherence and Fourier optics, lasers, holography, introduction of nonlinear optics

7. Advanced topics (Optional)
Super-resolution optical microscopy, optical trapping, metamaterials

courses.description: This course serves as an introduction to the central ideas of the theory of general relativity. The theory of special relativity is also reviewed and its geometric formulation will be introduced. Topics in the theory of special relativity include: Lorentz transformation, relativistic kinematics and dynamics, spacetime interval. Elements of differential geometry such as metric, vectors, covariant differentiation and curvature will also be introduced. Topics in the general theory of relativity include: gravity as spacetime curvature, geodesic equation, Einstein’s equations, Schwarzschild metric, black holes, gravitational waves, and cosmological models.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: PHYS3041 or its equivalents, or permission of the instructor.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students will be able to:
1. describe and explain the basic concepts and foundation of special and general relativity
2. analyze and solve problems in relativistic mechanics
3. manage the basic concepts of differential geometry required in general relativity
4. analyze physics in curved spacetime
5. identify important applications of relativity and explain strong-gravity physical phenomena
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Review of special relativity
Principles of special relativity, Lorentz transformation, experimental basis (cf standard University Physics textbooks)

2. Special relativistic mechanics
Spacetime interval, Minkowski metric, 4-vectors, relativistic kinematics and dynamics, energy and momentum, spacetime diagram (cf Cheng’s Ch 3; Hartle’s Ch 4-5; Schutz Ch 2)

3. Gravity as geometry
Equivalence principle, gravitational time dilation, Newtonian gravity and motion in spacetime description (cf Cheng’s Ch4; Hartle’s Ch 6)

4. Description of curved spacetime
Metric tensor, local inertial frames, vectors in curved spacetime (cf Hartle’s Ch 7)

5. Particle orbits in spherically symmetric spacetimes
Geodesic equation (derived from the variational principle for free particle motion), Schwarzschild spacetime (not derived), particle and light ray orbits, classic tests of GR (cf Cheng’s Ch 6-7; Hartle’s Ch 8-10)

6. Nonrotating Black hole
Local proper time vs Schwarzschild coordinate time, gravitational redshift, r=2M coordinate singularities and the event horizon (cf Cheng’s Ch8; Hartle’s 12)

7. Basic differential geometry
Tensors, covariant derivative, Christoffel symbols, geodesic equation (geometric viewpoint), Riemann curvature tensor, Bianchi identities and Einstein tensor (cf Cheng’s Ch 13; Hartle’s Ch 20-21)

8. Einstein equation
Tidal force as the curvature of spacetime, equation of geodesic deviation, energy-momentum tensor and local conservation law, principle of general covariance, Einstein equation and its Newtonian limit, Schwarzschild solution (cf Cheng’s 14; Hartle’s Ch 21-22; Schutz’s Ch 8)

9. Gravitational waves
Linearized Einstein equation, propagation of gravitational waves (GW), production of weak GW, quadrupole formula and GW sources, detection of GW (cf Cheng’s Ch 15; Hartle’s 16 & 23; Schutz’s Ch 9)

10. Special topics (if time is allowed)
Cosmology (cf Cheng’s Ch 9-10; Hartle’s Ch 17-18; Schutz’s Ch 12), rotating black holes (cf Hartle’s Ch 14-15), relativistic stars (cf Hartle’s Ch 24)

PHY [N] [/N] [T] [/T]

* *PHYS** **4****630 Other Physics Learning Experience**

# Course Description

| Students who have carried out project work or engaged in other physics learning experience related to physics or the training and application of generic skills in the physics curriculum off-campus, typically during exchange or internship programmes, may apply to register into the course. Assessment will be based on a project report and an oral presentation on the off-campus project work. Prerequisite: Permission of instructor. Grade Descriptors A : Demonstrate strong evidence of achieving all learning outcomes. Clear identification of the goal(s) of the project. Excellent planning and implementation of the project. Well-structured and accurate exposition of material in reports and presentation. Excellent teamwork skills. A- : Demonstrate strong evidence of achieving almost all the descriptors for grade A. B : Demonstrate evidence of achieving most learning outcomes. Identification of the goal(s) of the project, although the goals may not be well-defined and/or achievable. Effective planning and implementation of the project. Structured and mostly accurate exposition of material in reports and presentation. Good teamwork skills. C : Demonstrate evidence of achieving some learning outcomes. Unclear project goal(s). Insufficient planning and ineffective implementation of the project. Satisfactory structure and mostly accurate exposition of material in reports and presentation. Fair teamwork skills. D :. Demonstrate evidence of achieving only a few learning outcomes. Lack of project goal(s). Completion of projects within time limit despite lack of project planning. Unclear structure and inaccurate exposition of material in reports and presentation. Poor teamwork skills. F : Demonstrate no evidence of achieving learning outcomes, or failure to meet specified assessment requirements. Failure to understand the scope or nature of the project. Inability to complete the project. Illogical structure and inaccurate exposition of material in reports and presentation. Lack of teamwork. [/D] [/D] |
| --- |

* *Course Status: Elective,** **2-unit course**

# Learning Outcomes

At the completion of this course, the students will be able to:

| 1. | apply classroom knowledge in physics and other generic skills in project development [/O] |
| --- | --- |
| 2. | communicate information in a clear, concise and logical manner in written work and presentation |
| 3. | demonstrate good interpersonal skills and attitudes in teamwork |

* *Course Syllabus:**

The chosen theme of the course varies every year. The course integrates classroom knowledge in physics and stimulates students to engage in activities related to knowledge generation and dissemination

# Assessment Scheme

Report 60%.

In case of Study Tour, the report contains: (a) Reflection on study tour, (b) reflection on preparation of materials in pre-trip workshop, (c) scientific task data collection (e.g. solar eclipse photos and video). Assessment criteria: (a) Inclusion of reflection part and the quality of data collected in (c).

Presentation 40%

In case of Study Tour, the assessment criteria for presentation (engaging with the general public to promote science) are: (a) Good interaction with high school students, (b) teamwork in setting up equipment, (c) scientific accuracy in answering questions, and (d) Effective communication.

* *PHYS 4712 Short Experimental Project IV**

# Course Description

| This course aims at providing students with project learning experience in experimental physics. Student taking this course is required to finish a short experimental project, which illustrates modern physics and/or experimental technique. A project report in the format of a journal article is required. Prerequisite: permission of instructor. Grade Descriptors A : Demonstrate thorough mastery of the subject (of the project or seminar) required for attaining all the course learning outcomes. Demonstrate evidence of original thoughts and the ability of critical use of data or results to draw insightful conclusions, in a manner that would surpass the normal expectation at this level and standards that may be required at higher levels of study or research. Has the ability to express the knowledge and synthesis of ideas in a clear and cogent manner. A- : Demonstrate substantial command of the subject (of the project or seminar) required for attaining almost all the course learning outcomes. Demonstrate the ability of critical use of data or results to draw meaningful conclusions, in a manner that is logical and comprehensive. Has the ability to express the knowledge or application with clarity and accuracy. B : Demonstrate general and sufficient command of the subject (of the project or seminar) required for attaining most of the course learning outcomes. Demonstrate the ability of the use of data or results to draw mostly correct conclusions, in a manner that is logical and persuasive. Has the ability to express the knowledge or application in a satisfactory and unambiguous way. C : Demonstrate general command of the subject (of the project or seminar) required for attaining some of the course learning outcomes. Demonstrate the ability of the use of data or results to draw conclusions, but with occasional errors. Has the ability to express the separate pieces of knowledge in an unambiguous way. D : Demonstrate partial command the subject (of the project or seminar) required for attaining some of the course learning outcomes. Has limited ability to use data or results to draw conclusions. Has the ability to state the knowledge in simple terms. F : Demonstrate little or no evidence of command of subject (of the project or seminar) required for attaining the course learning outcomes, OR failure to meet specified assessment requirements. |

courses.subject: PHYS
courses.title: From Computational Physics to Artificial Intelligence
courses.description: This is an introductory level course for postgraduate students on various computational techniques and concepts of artificial intelligence adopted in the field of computational physics. This course provides an opportunity for students to learn and apply the artificial intelligence related techniques learned in the lecture to various research related projects. To prepare for this course, students are expected to have taken undergraduate level computational physics (PHYS3061 or equivalent) and have grasped fundamental skills in computer programming. The course will cover random processes, linear and nonlinear regression, clustering, neural network methods, machine learning applications in physics, and other advanced artificial intelligence topics such as Generative AI, large language model, etc. The student is expected to conduct several related programming projects and deliver a final presentation.

The registration of the course requires a permission of the instructor.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Good Understanding of important artificial intelligence related algorithms in physics
2. Development of the ability to apply artificial intelligence related algorithms in research project
3. Improvements in present skills of research project in a clear, concise, and logical manner.
4. Enhancement of the understanding in the general concepts of computational physics
5. Improvements of programming skills and parameter tuning abilities that are critical in computational physics research.

Chapter 2: Linear and non-linear regression
Chapter 3: Clustering analysis
Chapter 4: Neural networks (NNs)
Chapter 5: NNs application in physics
Chapter 6: Other machine learning applications in physics
Chapter 7: Selected advanced AI topics and applications in physics

courses.subject: PHYS
courses.title: Fundamentals of Modern Quantum Mechanics
courses.description: This course explores essential concepts and methods of modern quantum mechanics at the postgraduate level for Master of Science students. Topics covered include: Postulates of quantum mechanics, quantum state evolution and quantum measurements, path integral approach, and selected topics in modern applications of quantum mechanics.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For MSc Physics
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. To learn the formalism of quantum mechanics.
2. To learn the quantum dynamics of basic quantum systems such as two-level systems and harmonic oscillators.
3. To learn modern applications of quantum mechanics.

3. Dirac kets and operators in quantum mechanics
4. Formalism of quantum mechanics

6. Quantum dynamics
7. Adiabatic evolution and Berry phase
8. Quantum entanglement and applications

courses.subject: PHYS
courses.title: Principles of Thermal and Statistical Physics
courses.description: This is a graduate level introduction to thermal and statistical physics for Master of Science students. This course intends to cover laws of thermodynamics, statistical basis of thermodynamics, ensemble theory, and Fermi and Bose gases. Optional topics include interacting systems, quantum statistics, non-equilibrium dynamics, and phase transitions.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Physics
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. To learn the fundamental concepts of thermal and statistical physics.
2. To apply the concepts to different systems such as simple gases, Fermi and Bose systems.
3. To learn modern applications of thermodynamics and statistical mechanics.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Principles of Thermodynamics: the laws of thermodynamics, heat, work, and internal energy, entropy, potential, ideal and real gases, heat engines and refrigerators, the mathematical structures of the theory of thermodynamics such as Maxwell relations.
2. Principle of Statistical Mechanics: macro and micro states, probability theory, ensemble theories on micro-canonical and canonical ensembles, Boltzmann distribution, partition function, density of states, examples such as spin-1/2 paramagnet.
3. Bose gases: black body radiation, Debye theory, Bose-Einstein condensation.
4. Fermi gases: electron gas in a magnetic field, magnetism.
5. Statistical mechanics of interacting systems: van der Waals equation (optional).
6. Quantum system: density matrix (optional).
7. Phase Transitions and Critical Phenomena: order-disorder phase transitions, Ising and other models, mean field theories (optional).

courses.description: This graduate level course covers basic principles of electromagnetism for Master of Science students. Topics include: Maxwell’s equations, conservation laws, electromagnetic waves, potential theory, and electromagnetic radiation.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Physics
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students will be able to:

1. Apply Maxwell’s equations to describe basic electromagnetic systems.
2. Make use of electromagnetic potentials to solve Maxwell’s equations.
3. Calculate electromagnetic radiation from simple radiating systems.
4. Appreciate the role of special relativity in electromagnetism.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Electrostatics, magnetostatics and electromagnetic induction
2. Maxwell’s equations
3. Conservation laws in Maxwell’s theory
4. Electromagnetic waves in vacuum and linear media
5. Potential theory and retarded solutions
6. Radiation from time-dependent localized sources
7. Special relativity in electromagnetism

courses.subject: PHYS
courses.title: Advanced Quantum Mechanics
courses.description: This course will discuss various theoretical topics of non-relativistic quantum mechanics at the graduate level. The quantum mechanics of many-body systems will also be introduced. Topics covered include: operator methods in quantum mechanics, addition of angular momenta, variational method, stationary perturbation theory, time-dependent perturbation theory, scattering theory, and introduction to the quantum theory of many-body systems.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Physics; For students in MSc Physics; For students in MPhil-PhD Materials Sci & Erg;For students in BSc Physics
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. To further appreciate the basic principles of quantum mechanics, the axiom formalism, the superposition principle, and the quantum measurement principle.
2. To appreciate the foundation of quantum mechanics, with knowledge of some modern quantum physics concepts such as entanglement, quantum no-cloning theorem, the Bell inequalities, and the EPR paradox.
3. To understand the importance of symmetry in physics, to establish the relations between quantum transformations and symmetry transformations, and to connect the conservation laws to symmetries in the quantum mechanic formalism.
4. To learn systematically the general angular momentum, spins, angular momentum addition, and relations to selection rules.
5. To learn the formalism of quantum mechanics of identical particles, especially the second-quantization formalism and the (anti-)symmetrical states, and to carry out simple calculations of many-body systems.
6. To carry out perturbation calculation of near-degenerate systems and time-dependent perturbation calculation, and to understand the linear response theory.
7. To learn concepts and formalism of scattering, to carry out calculation of single-particle potential scattering in some simple cases, and to understand the concept of resonances.
8. To learn basic concepts of adiabatic evolution, geometrical phases, and the gauge field theory.
9. To learn the basic path-integral formalism of quantum mechanics.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Formalism of Quantum Mechanics
2. Review of some elementary applications
3. Two- and three-dimensional potentials; angular momentum; spin

courses.subject: PHYS
courses.title: Introduction to Soft Matter Physics
courses.description: The aim of this course is to provide students the basic concepts and research methods in soft matter physics. Topics covered include: Structural, thermodynamic and dynamical properties of macromolecules, gels, colloids, amphiphilic molecules, membranes and liquid crystals. Principles for some of the major experimental techniques used in soft matter research will also be discussed. Students who take this course are expected to have a good knowledge of thermodynamics and statistical mechanics.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Physics; For students in MSc Physics; For students in MPhil-PhD Materials Sci & Erg
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Have an appreciation of the basic concepts and research methods in soft matter physics.
2. Understand the basic difference between soft condensed matter and hard condensed in terms of energy scales, dominant forces and the role of entropy.
3. Understand and be able to apply in simple problems the concepts of coarse graining, polydispersity and radius of gyration.
4. Understand, through the Flory-Huggins mean-field theory, the interplay between the entropy of mixing and enthalpy of mixing in determining the equilibrium thermodynamic properties of soft matter systems, such as polymers and colloids.
5. Understand the phase diagram of binary systems, such as polymer solutions and colloidal suspensions.
6. Understand the essential physics behind scattering techniques through static and dynamics light scattering.
7. Know what physical quantities of soft matter systems can be measured through a combination of static and dynamic light scattering. Be able to derive the relationships between some simple structural and interaction parameters and measured quantities from light scattering.
8. Be able to gain basic understanding of other soft matter systems not covered in the lectures though the course project.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction
2. Thermodynamics of soft matter solutions
3. Phase separation in soft matter solutions
4. Mechanical properties of soft matter
5. Diffusion Process
6. Colloidal suspensions
7. Polymer solutions
8. Ionic soft matter
9. Interfacial phenomena
10. Project presentations

courses.subject: PHYS
courses.title: Instrumentation II
courses.description: Principles, instrumentation, experiments and data interpretation of spectroscopy, thermal analysis, microscopy and other instrumentation. Laboratory experiments for practice and illustration of the subject matter.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Physics; For students in MSc Physics; For students in MPhil-PhD Materials Sci & Erg
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. To gain a general understanding of the development of modern instrumentations and know their significance to the society.
2. To make connections of the concepts acquired in other physics courses (e.g. thermal physics, quantum physics and solid state physics) to practical experiments.
3. To realize that one should know the working principles in order to gain deep understandings when performing research with these modern instruments.
4. To learn some commonly used experimental techniques and facilities in physics research, and have the knowledge of other instrumentations not discussed in details at the class.
5. To gain hands-on experience with available modern instruments in the department by carrying out some experiments, such as thermal analysis, atomic force microscopy, and optical microscopy.
6. To acquire experimental skills related to their research for further studies.
courses.course_syllabus:
Transducers and sensors: (~ 5 lectures)
Types of transducers and sensors. Figures of merit of transducers and sensors: Accuracy, repeatability, resolution, sensitivity, dynamic range.

Signal conditioning, propagation and conversion: (~ 4 lectures)
Amplification: gain, bandwidth, gain bandwidth product, impedance matching.
Analog-digital conversion and sampling: analog to digital, digital to analog, Nyquist theorem aliasing. Transmission media: types, bandwidth and noise restrictions.

Noise: (~ 4 lectures)
Sources of fundamental noise, thermal noise, shot noise, 1/f noise, signal to noise ratio, noise equivalent power and detectability. Environmental noise: sources and minimization, electrical pickup, electromagnetic interference and radio frequency interference, power-line-coupled noise, ground loops, shielding, grounding.

Signal Transmission: (~ 3 lectures)
Filtering and discriminating, averaging. Phase sensitive detection, multichannel averager, gated integrator.

Vacuum techniques: (~ 4 lectures)
Pumps: rotary, diffusion, turbomolecular, ion, cryo. Seals, flanges, feedthroughs, and valves.
Pressure gauges: thermoconductive, ion, Penning. Gas flow: controllers, flowmeters. Leak detection.

Instrumentation for Integrated-circuit fabrication: (~2 lectures)
Epitaxial growth, masking, etching, plasma etching.

Medical Instrumentation: (~2 lectures)
EEG, ECG, EMG, magnetic resonance imaging, tomography.

courses.subject: PHYS
courses.title: Topics in Theoretical Physics (Advanced Statistical Mechanics)
courses.description: This course provides an introduction to the major ideas and methods in equilibrium statistical mechanics as well as in nonequilibrium statistical physics. Topics will be selected from the statistical mechanics of magnetic systems; interacting fluids and soft matter; theory of critical phenomena and the renormalization group; stochastic dynamics and nonequilibrium processes; introduction to quantum statistical mechanics; and other topics of current interest in statistical physics.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Physics; For students in MSc Physics; For students in MPhil-PhD Materials Sci & Erg
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. To appreciate the universality of critical phenomena.
2. To understand the key concepts in modern statistical physics including order parameter, symmetry breaking, elementary excitations, and emergent phenomena.
3. To learn the formalism of quantum statistics.
4. To understand the roles of long-range fluctuations in phase transitions and critical phenomena, the scaling hypothesis, the decimation method, and the concepts of renormalization group.
5. To carry out calculation of thermodynamic functions for interacting systems with statistical mechanics techniques such as cluster expansion, mean-field approximation, and renormalization group method. To understand the limitation of the mean-field approximation.
6. To understand basic concepts of topological phase transitions and topological excitations.
7. To acquire knowledge about typical statistical mechanics models such as non-ideal gases, alloys, liquid crystals, quantum magnetism models, Ising models and exact solutions, and two-dimensional classical spin models.

5. Symmetry breaking, order parameter
6. Collective modes and statistical fields
7. Landau-Ginzburg phenomenological theory
8. Fluctuations, scaling, critical phenomena
9. Perturbative and lattice renormalization group

courses.subject: PHYS
courses.title: Topics in Theoretical Physics (Astrophysics)
courses.description: This is a graduate course which covers various topics in theoretical astrophysics in one of the following areas: (1) Plasma physics and its applications in astrophysical phenomena, (2) Astroparticle Physics. For area (1), basic concepts in plasma physics such as plasma waves, shocks, MHD instabilities and magnetic reconnection are introduced. In addition, illustrations from astrophysics such as solar flares, cosmic rays, interstellar turbulence, and protostellar disks will be discussed. For area (2), current topics in Astroparticle physics including Big Bang nucleosynthesis, content and dynamics of the Universe, Cosmic rays, Neutrino astrophysics, and Dark matter will be discussed, with emphasis on how fundamental processes at the particle level impact astrophysical and cosmological evolution. In both areas, experimental and observational studies will be discussed in parallel with basic theory.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Physics, MSc Physics or MPhil-PhD Materials Science & Engineering
courses.learning_outcomes:
For Area (1):
1. Understand the definition of plasma and various models aiming to describe plasma with different degrees of approximation.
2. Know which models to apply for various astronomical environments.
3. Understand astronomical phenomena based on plasma physics.
4. Apply plasma physics to other fields.

For Area (2):
1. Understand the content and the evolution of the Universe.
2. Have a basic understanding of particle physics, including particle interaction and detection.
3. Understand various phenomena and puzzles in the astrophysics and cosmology.
4. Understand how particles are used as a tool to probe various phenomena, including some modern applications.
courses.course_syllabus:
For Area (1):
1. Basic concepts: Definition of plasma; astronomical examples; Debye shielding; quasi-neutrality.
2. Vlasov, two-fluid and MHD models: Distribution function andVlasov equation; two-fluid equation; MHD equations; flux squeezing.
3. Motion in a non-uniform magnetic field: adiabatic invariants; drift equation; WKB method.
4. Plasma waves: Small-amplitude waves; Alfven waves; two-fluid model of Alfven modes; MHD waves.
5. MHD shocks and instability: Nonlinear steeping; shock thickness; shock waves; energy principle; interchange instability; Parker instability; magnetorotational instability.
6. Collision: Fokker-Planck equation; the fluid equation; transport effects; the Braginski equation.
7. Collisionless plasma: Dispersion relation for cold plasma waves; parallel/perpendicular propagation; Faraday rotation; Bremsstrahlung; thermal effects; ion acoustic wave; Landau damping; resonances.
8. Nonlinear phenomena Wave-particle interactions; wave-wave interactions; mode decay; nonlinear Landau damping; Kolmogorov turbulence; MHD turbulence.
9. Magnetic reconnection on solar surface and molecular clouds: Sweet-Parker model; Uzdensky model; Petschek’s model; Non-MHD reconnection; Hall reconnection.
10. Dusty plasmas in protostellar disks: Dust charge; dust acoustic waves; dust ion acoustic waves; crystallization.

For Area (2)
1. Standard Model of Particle Physics: Basic properties of fundamental subatomic particles and their possible interactions; detection of particles.
2. Big Bang Cosmology: Overview of the content and dynamics of the evolution of the universe; expansion of the universe.
3. Big Bang Nucleosynthesis: Production of light elements in hot Big Bang; constraints on fundamental interactions and particle content.
4. Cosmic rays: Fermi acceleration; astrophysical shock waves; Cosmic-ray propagation; measurement of cosmic rays.
5. Neutrino Astrophysics: Stellar neutrinos; supernova neutrinos; high-energy astrophysical and cosmogenic neutrinos; neutrino oscillations; neutrino experiments.
6. Dark matter astrophysics and cosmology: Observational evidences of dark matter; cosmological structure formation; direct and indirect detection.
7. Optional current research topics: Supernovae (types and observational signatures; mechanisms and dynamics); CMB B modes; dark energy models; inflationary cosmology; etc.

courses.subject: PHYS
courses.title: Modern Atomic Physics
courses.description: This course will discuss various fundamental topics of modern atomic physics at the postgraduate level. The first part of the course focuses on atomic structures, the semi-classical theory of atom-light interactions and their application to the understanding of laser cooling and related topics. The second part is on atom-atom interactions at ultracold temperatures, including its application to evaporative cooling for reaching quantum degeneracy. An advanced topics section is also included to introduce the most recent developments in this field. Students should have undergraduate level Quantum Mechanics before taking this course.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
For MSc Physics
For MPhil-PhD Materials Sci & Erg
For MPhil-PhD Physics
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. To apply the fundamental knowledge of quantum mechanics to understand atomic structures.
2. To understand interactions between light-atom, and atom-atom and to solve common real-world problems.
3. To understand the physical basis of the recent development in ultracold AMO physics.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Review of quantum mechanics: Schrödinger’s equation, probability density, operator and Hamiltonian, observables, uncertainty principle, angular momentum, spin.
2. Atomic structure: Hydrogen atom, fine structure, hyperfine structure, alkali atoms, Zeeman Effect, Stark Effect.
3. Atom-light interaction: Einstein coefficients, driven two-level systems, Rabi frequency, density matrix and optical Bloch equations, relaxation, saturation and lineshape, Doppler-free laser spectroscopy.
4. Laser cooling and trapping: Scattering force, slowing of atomic beams, optical molasses, cooling limits, magneto-optical trap, optical dipole trap.
5. Ultracold collisions, evaporative cooling: Introduction to scattering theory, partial wave expansion, scattering length, elastic scattering, inelastic collisions, evaporative cooling.
6. Bose Einsten condensation of dilute atomic gases: Critical temperature, condensate fraction, macroscopic wave function, Gross-Pitaevskii equation, Thomas-Fermi approximation.

courses.recommended_readings:

3. W. Demtröder, Laser Spectroscopy: Basic Concepts and Instrumentation, 2nd Edition, Springer-Verlag, 1996, ISBN 3-540-57171-X.
4. Marcis Auzinsh, Dmitry Budker, Simon Rochester, Optically Polarized Atoms: Understanding light-atom interactions, ISBN-13: 978-0199565122.

courses.description: Biophysics investigates biological phenomena using theoretical and experimental approaches derived from physics, such as statistical mechanics, fluid mechanics, and optics. This course provides an introduction to biophysics for postgraduate students with no biology background. Students will be introduced to basic biology and physics concepts relevant to the course, followed by topics including the functions of biomolecules, dynamics of regulatory networks, physics of cellular behavior, and recent development of frontier biophysics techniques. Through this course, students will become familiar with the scope and basic approaches of biophysics research, learn how to perform computer simulations on biomolecules, and develop interest in exploring new territories of biophysics. Students should have undergraduate level thermodynamics and statistical mechanics before taking this course.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSc Physics, MPhil-PhD Materials Sci & Erg or MPhil-PhD Physics
courses.learning_outcomes:
(1) To understand basic concepts in biophysics.
(2) To develop knowledge of commonly-used methods in computational and experimental biophysics research.
(3) To develop interest in applying physics concepts and tools to study living systems.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction to biology: Proteins and other biomolecules inside cells; Central dogma of molecular biology; Types of cells.
2. Basic concepts in biophysics: Friction and diffusion; Energy, entropy, Brownian motors; Water as the solvent for life; Viscosity and low-Reynolds number world.
3. Molecules, machines and mechanisms; Enzymes and molecular machines; Membranes and machines in membranes; Bioelectricity and nerve impulses.
4. Techniques in biophysics research: Computer modeling and simulation; Molecular dynamics simulations; Commonly used programs and force fields; analysis of simulation results. A brief survey of single-molecule techniques.
courses.required_readings: Please refer to Recommended Readings.
courses.recommended_readings:
1. Physical biology of the cell / Rob Phillips, Jane Kondev, Julie Theriot, New York : Garland Science, c2009.
2. Biological physics : energy, information, life/ Philip Nelson ; New York : W.H. Freeman, c2004.
3. Molecular and cellular biophysics / Meyer B. Jackson; Cambridge : Cambridge University Press, 2006.
4. Machinery of Life [electronic resource] / by David S. Goodsell. New York, NY : Springer-Verlag New York, 2009.

courses.subject: PHYS
courses.title: Topics in Experimental Physics (Thin Film Physics and Technology)
courses.description: This course provides an introduction to the physical properties of thin films as well as the preparation methods. Topics covered include: vacuum science and technology, thin film deposition techniques, growth processes and modes, characterization, epitaxy, lattice engineering, optical and electrical properties of thin films. State-of-the-art scientific research on thin film preparation and properties will also be selectively introduced.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Physics; For students in MSc Physics; For students in MPhil-PhD Materials Sci & Erg
courses.learning_outcomes:
(1) To know the technologies that involve thin films.
(2) To understand the basic principles of vacuum science and technology that are related to thin-film deposition techniques.
(3) To understand the thermodynamics of evaporation and learn the basic principles of evaporation.
(4) To acquire the basic knowledge about adsorption, surface diffusion, nucleation, and structure development that are involved in thin-film deposition.
(5) To acquire the basic knowledge of epitaxial deposition.
(6) To learn the basic knowledge of chemical vapor deposition.
(7) To learn the basic techniques of measuring the physical and chemical properties of thin films.
courses.course_syllabus:
1: Introduction to Thin Film Technology
2: Vacuum Science and Technology
3: Evaporation
4: Deposition
5: Epitaxy
6: Chemical Vapor Deposition
7: Film Analysis
8: Properties of Thin Films

courses.subject: PHYS
courses.title: Semiconductor Physics and Devices
courses.description: This course discusses the physics of semiconductors and the principles behind selected applications. The physics of the electronic band structures, electrons and holes dynamics, effects of impurities, semiconductor statistics, and lattice vibrations will be discussed, using the technologically important semiconductors such as Si, Ge, and GaAs as examples. Transport properties and optical properties of semiconductors will then be treated. The principles of some common devices based on semiconductors will be introduced. The physics of selected semiconductor heterostructures will also be discussed. Using semiconductors as the context, the students will learn and appreciate how quantum physics, statistical physics, and elementary solid state physics can be applied to understand much of semiconducting materials, which have transformed and will continue to transform technologies and the world.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Physics; For students in MSc Physics; For students in MPhil-PhD Materials Sci & Erg
courses.course_syllabus:
Topics to be discussed include:
Structures and bonding
Electronic energy bands
Electronic effects of impurities
Electrons and holes dynamics
Semiconductor statistics
Lattice vibrations
Transport properties
Optical properties
Principles of p-n junctions and related devices
Semiconductor lasers and photodevices
Heterostructures, superlattices and nanostructures
Applications of heterostructures
Metal-semiconductor devices

courses.title: MSc Dissertation
courses.description: A dissertation in physics for M.Sc. students only. The dissertation provides an opportunity for students to apply their knowledge acquired in lecture courses to carry out independent research. To prepare for this course, students are expected to have taken a Guided Study course or are taking a Guided Study course concurrently on a related topic by the same teaching staff (the supervisor). A combination of the literature review in the guided study and the application of the knowledge learned in the guided study and other lecture courses to investigate related physical problems should be performed. The student should report his/her progress to the supervisor on a regular basis. The dissertation to be written under the guidance of the supervisor is required. An oral presentation should be conducted to a dissertation committee of the supervisor and another invited teaching staff.
